reviewText:
"A Most Wanted Man" (2014 release; 121 min.) is the big screen adaptation of the John Le Carre novel of the same name. As the movie opens, we see some guy entering the port of Hamburg, Germany in a covert way. We later learn he is Issa, an alleged jihadist who has fled Chechnya, Russia for fear of prosecution. In a parallel story line, we get to know Gunther Bachmann (played by Philip Seymour Hoffman), who heads an anti-terror unit in the German security forces. Gunther and his colleague Erna (played by Nina Hoss) are quickly on the trail of Issa. Meanwhile, through mutual connections, Issa is put in touch with Annabel Richter (played by Rachel McAdams), a lawyer defending the causes of asylum seekers. To tell you more of the story would spoil your viewing experience of this plot-heavy movie, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.

Couple of comments: first, this is the latest movie from Dutch director Anton Corbijn, best known for his extensive visual design and video work for Depeche Mode and other bands. He also brought us "Control", the biopic about Joy Division's Ian Curtis. In this film, he stays more in the direction of his most recent film, "The American" (starring George Clooney). As you can expect, the visuals in "A Most Wanted Man" are given plenty of attention and detail. Hamburg (the city) is as much a character in the movie as are the key performers. Second, the movie itself works quite well. Compared to the previous John Le Carre adaptation for the big screen, 2011's disastrous "Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy", this movie is a masterpiece, albeit not without flaws. The movie keeps us guessing for much of the time as to what really is going on (primarily: is Issa ultimately a "good" guy or a "bad" guy?), and that keeps the tension of the movie up (in a good way). Third, this movie is, sadly, best known for being one of the very last on screen performances of Philip Seymour Hoffman. He does his usual great work, even with the funny faux German accent, but I have to say that he does not look well or at ease. The (literally) non-stop smoking during the entire movie surely does not help. There are quite a few other to take note of: Willem Dafoe as the (sleazy? good?) banker, Robin Wright as the American Embassy envoye, Rachel McAdams as the well-intended asylum lawyer, and last but certainly not least, Nina Hoss as Gunther's colleague. She is in my humble opinion one of Europe's top actresses of this generation, with such recent films as "Barbara", "Yerichow" and "Yella". Hoss brings a much needed spark to "A Most Wanted Man". Finally, there is a nice orchestral score for this movie, composed by German musician Herbert Grönemeyer.

The movie came out 3 weeks or so ago here in Cincinnati but for whatever reason I didn't get to see it until now. Imagine my surprise that the matinee screening where I saw this at this weekend was very well attended. Mostly an older audience I might add. I surmise that this being a John Le Carre adaptation plays a huge factor in people coming to check this movie out. Bottom line: "A Most Wanted Man" is a satisfactory spy-thriller with several stellar acting performances, in particular Philip Deymour Hoffman and Nina Hoss. "A Most Wanted Man" is definitely worth checking out, be it in the theater or on DVD/Bly-ray.

A MOST WANTED MAN, (2014), is a current-day all-star thriller, set in dark, dense, gritty Hamburg, an ancient German port.  The approximately two hour film is based on the rather recent book of the same name by illustrious British spymeister John LeCarre, he of the long life and long prolific career.  The screenplay was written by Andrew Bovell; Anton Corbijn directed.  The picture tells the story of a young man, half-Russian, half-Chechen, who had been brutally tortured, and slips into Hamburg as a stowaway on a freighter from Turkey.  Once in Germany, he is taken in by its large Islamic community.

The illegal immigrant's arrival is noticed by German and American security agencies, whose interest in him deepens as he gets himself a blond German lawyer/social worker/do-gooder type, and lays claim to his late Russian father's huge ill-gotten fortune.

As is known by many, the movie stars the Oscar-winning Philip Seymour Hoffman, (CAPOTE), the mega-talented actor, in his last towering performance before his recent widely-mourned death. As Gunther Bachmann, obscure German functionary with tiny staff charged with preventing the next 9/11 attack by Islamic extremists, (which had been planned in Hamburg), Hoffman is in most scenes, and, with cigarette always in hand,  carries the picture seemingly effortlessly.  He receives top backing from the rest of the cast.  Grigorly Dobrygin plays Issa Karpov, the movie's tragic titular character.  Golden Globe winner Robin Wright, (THE PRINCESS BRIDE, FORREST GUMP) plays Martha Sullivan, Gunther's more powerful, better equipped American opposite.  The cute Rachel McAdams, (MEAN GIRLS, MIDNIGHT IN PARIS), plays Annabel Richter, Karpov's lawyer, in, to me, the film's only miscasting: she lacks the gravitas for the part, which, I think, needed a young Tilda Swinton.  Willem Dafoe (THE ENGLISH PATIENT) plays Tommy Brue, head of the bank his father founded, which has never been too particular about its depositors or their deposits.  In this typically for LeCarre, low-volume film, Gunther knows what he needs to do in this situation, knows what he needs to get the job done, and knows what he has available.  He must beg for men and materiel to do it.

The viewer gets to see a lot of Hamburg  in the film, and, believe me, it carries its weight with centuries-old muscle .  Officially the  Free and Hanseatic City of Hamburg, it is the second largest city in Germany. home to over 1.8 million people, while the Hamburg metropolitan region has more than 5 million inhabitants. On the river Elbe, out of the Baltic Sea, the port of Hamburg, now an affluent industrial/media powerhouse and transportation hub, is the second largest port in Europe (after  Rotterdam). Its official name reflects its history as a member of the medieval Hanseatic League, as a free imperial city of the Holy Roman Empire, and as a city-state, one of the 16 states of Germany; a sovereign state before Germany's1871 unification.

Hoffman turns in a powerful performance in a powerful movie.  A MOST WANTED MAN is an intelligent, dark contemporary tale of intrigue, love, rivalry, and politics.  It is cerebral, slow, no car crashes, gunplay, computer generations or blood, melancholy, and it can be confusing -- difficult to follow.  But it keeps up the tension right through to its last devastating scenes.  Be aware though, it does display the anti-American, anti-Israeli feelings that LeCarre apparently quietly holds in tune with much of the British upper crust, which have been displayed in much of his work.  But the author is a great story teller who knows his spy business, and his novel has here been brought to vivid, moving life.  I don't think you want to miss it.

This is an excellent movie of its genre.

As I watched it, I drew comparisons with Martin Ritt's "The Spy who came in from the Cold"- another superb adaptation of a Le Carre novel, featuring Richard Burton as a world weary spy.

The cast is uniformly excellent, delivering nuanced portrayals of complex characters. Philip Seymour Hoffman portrays the archetypal Le Carre spy masterfully. His performance stands comparison with that of Richard Burton in "The Spy who came in from the Cold".

Mr Corbijn's direction is restrained and effective in presenting a realistic picture of espionage. As a matter of interest, Mr Le Carre is an executive producer.

What is the story about? In post 9/11 Hamburg, a tight knit German counter terrorist organisation recruits spies and conducts covert surveillance in the fight against terrorism. Besides the challenge of performing their role, there's friction and rivalry  between the group and other counter terrorism authorities. It's a typical Le Carre tale- not everything is as it seems.  If you like the Le Carre style, you will enjoy this film; if not, you may find it a chore to watch.

Highly recommended for aficionados of Le Carre.

Enter and Exit Philip Seymour Hoffman. Alas, this is the last film of the best actor of the last decade.

PSH is Gnter Bachmann, German anti terror spy with smoking, drinking, and weight problems.
On his job, in Hamburg, where 9-11 had been prepared. He is doing reasonably well. His team has found the whereabouts of a suspicious Chechen illegal. They have also made progress in their quest of discovering how a famous liberal Muslim intellectual, a Hamburg resident, manages to channel funds into terror networks...

Where Gnter Bachmann doesn't do so well is cooperation and coordination with other German law enforcement agencies. Even worse is alignment with CIA policies. Enough said.
Brilliant PSH in a typical low key, dark Le Carr story. The whole cast is outstanding., with some German stars in small roles.
Some reviewers have complained that the actors speak with artificial German accents. It is not really a big issue though.
An appropriate special effect: Robin Wright's CIA agent never learns how to pronounce Gnter Bachmann's name. That fits their level of mutual trust.
On the other hand, Dafoe, who plays a banker, should have tried harder to pronounce the name of Rachel McAdams' character Annabel Richter, a lawyer.
And in case that you wondered about my headline: yes, it is irony. Taken from the film. It is said twice, first by the CIA woman, later by Bachmann, shortly before the big betrayal.

Hollywood has never been more enamored with the tradecraft novels of John le Carr than they are right now, having gained in popularity in this post 9/11 society of ours. But for me, I've always had something of a love/hate relationship with his work. While the murky games of spies and dark government assets is one le Carre knows better than anybody, the realism of his writing doesn't always make for the greatest entertainment. Every now and then you wish a car would blow up or somebody would fire a rocket launcher or something. Much like the most recent le Carre adaptation, Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy, A Most Wanted Man is another pot boiler with a great cast and a story that emphasizes facts, figures, and mood while leaving character in the background.

Philip Seymour Hoffman brings a palpable weariness to the role of Gunther Bachmann, an espionage operative in Hamburg, a country trying to overcome its reputation as a hot bed of terrorist activity. Gunther is part of an organization so secret, so deep in the weeds nobody knows who they report to. They operate on their own, preventing any security threats in a way they see fit. Like many of le Carre's most popular protagonists, Gunther is a shrewd, calculating man who is smarter and tougher than his physical appearance would suggest. He's a man called on to make the hard decisions because he always does.

When a battered and starving half-Chechnyan, half-Russian man emerges out of nowhere seeking political asylum, it catches the attention of not only Gunther's agency, but the CIA (represented by Robin Wright) and other departments in Germany. Gunther's investigation into whether this man is truly who he says, or perhaps a terrorist in disguise, is undermined at every turn by those who claim to be on his side. The ways of spies are often like the mafia; it's your friend with the biggest smile who sticks in the knife. The situation becomes cloudier when a local banker and civil rights advocate (Rachel McAdams) gets involved, along with a shady money man (Willem Dafoe) who is hired to help the refugee gain access to a sizable inheritance.

The second international thriller by Anton Corbijn (he directed George Clooney in The American); the film gets off to a slow start and never gains any momentum. Not that a le Carre story ever aims for big sizzle, the lack of energy is especially burdensome since there is so little interest in developing any of these characters. By contrast, an excellent le Carre adaptation like The Constant Gardener has a central figure with a personal stake in finding a hidden truth. It's no less analytical than A Most Wanted Man or 'Tinker Tailor', but there's an attempt to tell a story, not just go over procedures. And it's a shame because Hoffman really is great as Gunther, a man carrying the weight of the world on his shoulders. The entire veteran cast, and yes that includes McAdams wielding a convincing German accent, fit into le Carre's world perfectly. Ultimately, A Most Wanted Man is too stiff and calculating to appeal to anybody but the most die-hard fan of the genre.
An outstanding movie. A shocker of an ending. A must see!

Under the cover of night, a Chechen man quietly enters Germany via the Hamburg port.  He soon becomes the subject of a manhunt and part of German spies' investigation into a wealthy Muslim's humanitarian activity; they believe, amidst many legitimate charities, he is financing Islamic radicals.  The aforementioned spies' leader is played by the late (and great) Philip Seymour Hoffman in his final lead role.  It is a riveting, though largely quiet performance consisting of cigarettes, sideways glances, and an authentic air of old-pro exhaustion.  This suspenseful spy drama is adapted from a novel by the celebrated John le Carr, the 82-year-old anti-Ian Fleming.  Audience members who know past le Carr adaptations, including The Spy Who Came in from the Cold and The Constant Gardener, will find neither the content nor the tone very surprising:  the film is a restrained portrait of espionage agents as grey-scale civil servants forced to weigh the complicated result of their twisted, often brutal actions and responses against the final result.

Here, the Hoffman character's vision of spying (quietly creating, even seducing, a system of informants and watching the streets closely) is compared and contrasted with the Western world's recent embrace of such brute-force and controversial practices as extraordinary rendition, in which a suspect is abducted and spirited abroad for questioning and torture.  American power is represented here by Robin Wright, extra icy.  In general, the film is defined by its parade of old-fashioned, but robust and welcome spy-game pleasures.  Nothing is a particular revelation, but the moral conundrums ring true, the urban spaces have a menacing atmosphere, and the tightly woven storyline draws viewers in early and holds them firmly until the final crosses and double-crosses.
Slow moving, not much action, but good characters.
GREAT MOVIE!
Good book and I enjoyed the read

A MOST WANTED MAN

An experienced German espionage agent [Philip Seymour Hoffman] trusts his superiors, internal German police and American espionage agents. He tries to conduct a successful espionage operation but in the end everyone he contacts is arrested.

From the beginning a wary German agent [Hoffman] lets his guard down. He is open, revealing everything. The denouement shows Hoffman telling of his plans, including the transfer of money to characters in an office building and how everyone involved with leave. What is annoying is the absence of spyycraft. Most of the people Hoffman meets leave by the front door, together.

More shocking is Hoffman is on the street and does not notice surveillance, or the people ready to make arrests.

If one is a wary spy, supposedly throughout the story, he must be wary at the end. People assembled in the office ought to leave individually by various exits - racing from the garage on a motorcycle, crawling three blocks through air conditioning vents or jumping off the roof and sailing along in a hang glider - that sort of thing, those sorts of thing. None of these happen. Spy Hoffman is surprised and enfeebled. He reveals he is unfit for the espionage business.

Thereupon, other than seeing Hoffman in his last movie, this is a film to avoid.

Depressing take on the status of counter-terrorism, suggesting that the United States is a monster-force unable to truly understand the ideologies of Islamic extremist until its assessed from a European perspective. Make no mistake, its very intentional that American stars are playing European characters. The modern day dilemmas are what shape the infrastructure of the fictional story: Chechens are constantly suspected, no one wants anything to do with Russia, Germany has an under appreciated role, no one trusts Muslims, and the United States is the revenge-seeking Old Testament God. Similar to Zero Dark Thirty (2013), it emphasizes the tedious time consuming process to legally and efficiently apprehend a criminal. Opportunities will present themselves, act on them. Fans of the television show House of Cards" should appreciate the superb casting of Robin Wright as the U.S. ambassador. A Most Wanted Man is not a propaganda piece for anti-torture; its a chess match of politics and ideologies where the ultimate winner is the one who can truly understanding the mindset of where people come from, what they do, and what propels their actions.
Dry, slow.
Slow out of the shoot....just an average flick at best.
Very exciting movie. Well written with great actors.
Just not good. Lost interest.

This really was a total surprise. Not a huge fan of Philip Thomas Anderson...uh, Philip Seymour Hoffman. Nothing wrong with him and he's a good actor but not really going out of my way to track down movies where he's the lead really. Even though I couldn't quite figure out why they used American actors to play German people especially actors that are not exactly HUGE box office draws, I still enjoyed this flick immensely.

It's from a John Le Carre novel and the extras threw me for a loop. The guy is still alive and this is a modern book! I thought it must've been some adaptation of one of his Cold War era German spy novels.

Willem Dafoe is in it. I know! Rachel MacAdams. I know! This is a heavy hitting cast and they all hit it over the wall (super special Anton Corbijn Bunnymen shoutout and East German pun for those of you who enjoy that).

The setting of Hamburg is brilliant as the city itself seems (no, is!) like a character in the movie. The issue of fear of terrorists, immigration and the new Europe is really done well with as much nuance as there is in the real Europe of today.

All in all, I was totally surprised and none more so that the guy who photographed two of the most isonic (and greatest!) album covers from the '80s (Echo & the Bunnymen's Heaven Up Here and Porcupine) is now an accomplished movie director. Just fantastic!
Great Condition
Boring
A very intelligent, compelling spy film; Hoffman's performance is brilliant.
I had high expectations for this based on the book but was disappointed. I believe I expected too much.
GOING TO MISS P.S.H.

Acting is amateurish. Fake German accents are at times unbearable. No sense of the place. They forgot the character called Germany. The casting was very weak. CIA woman was a flat character played by an uncharismatic actress. Even Defoe is pathetic with his Hollywood-German accent.

The lead actress is a completely awful actress. Really ruins the movie.

Also, this movie seems to simply back up the blind fear of Muslim people, and for most the movie has no evidence as to why we're suspicious of the main Muslim character. The paradigm here is pretty much the far right's tacit attitude.

Finally, they don't seem to have watched any spy movies or read any spy novels. This is basically a cop movie with surveillance. No real espionage intrigue here. Falls far short of the genre.

Also, the moving / wobbling hand held camera thing ruins the experience of watching this movie, and makes you aware that you're watching a movie throughout. This whole new amateurish camera work is really ruining so many movies and show, that otherwise may be tolerable. Bad concept.

A you-don't-have-to-see-it movie. I turned it off half way through.

Slow, boring and a waste of money to rent. What a disappointment!
Buy in some other format. Had to fight through multiple trash movie "previews" to get to the movie.
Good,suspenful,movie. Philip Seymour Hoffman is great as usual. He is such an accomplished actor.
So believable.  Excellent acting on location that draws you into the story that leave you a bit cold at the end.  But then again that's John Le Carre for you.
Enjoyable

Hoffman at his best. I can relate. The somewhat cynical flawed man trying to do good nonetheless, and then there's the rest of the world and all it's flaws. Perhaps too close to the reality of this situation and job and agencies and politics, unfortunately.
Very slow moving,  not much action and sort of boring.
One of the best movies made, especially by PSH!  Sorry to have lost him.
Something wonderfully hypnotic about this movie. Seen it three times already!

What more do you need to say to a movie that stars Phillip Seymour Hoffman. His work is sadly missed. Although this was on a lower key then I would have thought, his acting just memorizes you and you can never get enough. We liked it, not loved it but truly liked it. I will say if any other actor was playing his roll I would not be giving such a review.
The fact that I can't remember it says it all.
Wow, boring

not a lot of action, but a good story

ok.. not bad

EXTREMELY WELL ACTED BY PHILIP SEYMOUR HOFFMAN

This is a fabulous thriller/spy movie featuring some of the biggest movie stars; to name a few: Phillip Seymour Hoffman, Willem Defoe, Robin Wright and Rachel McAdams.  It is a story that will keep you on he edge of the seat from start to finish.  Hoffman is feeding the story with so much emotion, it is impossible to let it go long after the movie is over.

Story is set is Hamburg, Germany.  It shows a struggle between various agencies that are fighting and infiltrating terrorist groups that movie around Europe but also support activities around the world, particularly middle east.  German security forces are in alliance with US anti-terrorism forces, but each agency and every player in this game has something at stake.

Rachel McAdams plays a young and idealistic German lawyer from well to do family trying to help Chechen radical change his ways and start a normal life in Germany.  Defoe plays a banker whose deceased father's business connections still have a stake at the bank he is managing.  He is at the crossroads, both personal and professional although it does not take much effort to convince him to work in favor of the German government.

All actors, particularly Hoffman deliver unforgettable performances.  It is amazing to watch this story unfold.  It is almost as if one is watching one of John LeCarre's novels. Only Hoffman's character Gunther is more haunted than any of the characters I have seen in spy movies so far.

I'd hoped for a better conclusion and the one given, which fails to end matters in a fully satisfactory manner.
Otherwise, an intriguing film on German police methods, and the politics that intercepts, and interferes, with policing worldwide.

If a movie is supposed to be in Europe, anywhere, the actors should have good accents. The actors, for the most part, do not have good authentic sounding accents, and they change from one sentence to the next. It's a somewhat interesting story, though.
Amazing story & cast !!!!!!
Enjoyed

Awesome

The story intrigued this viewer; the characters captured me and made the story believable. The painful ending shocked and reminded me that this was a story by Le Carre.
Well written and well acted.  Very interesting plot.  Have watched it twice and enjoyed both viewings. A bit slow in places but very well done.

I found this movie very interesting.

Solid film with a near perfect performance from Hoffman in one of his last films. Not without its flaws though.
Great movie. Deep. Thought provoking.

A big, brooding, character Phillip Seymour Hoffman is in this great film, 'A Most Wanted Man".  Great actor. His presence in this film is, shall I say, is both physically large, particularly the camera angles, but emotionally he is both the paint and the canvas of this film. He and the movie come off as large. The subjects that the film tackles are large. Nifty camera work too. Subtle yet powerful connections between the characters. Unspoken loudness in this one.. Remember that when you see the kiss.  About the kiss: if you aint watching and listening, it happens so unexpectedly that you could miss it. LOL.  This is a thoughtful film. Im kind of reluctant to call it a "movie" because its "no bang bang shoot em up big explosions and fireballs".  The main actor, Phillip Seymour Hoffman, I knew I'd seen him in something else. And I know that I enjoyed him in his portrayal of that role, which escaped me. Some actors pull you into the film, into the plot. Here the plot is subtle, simmering very very low, like something on the back burner of your stove,  But in this film, the plot has multiple pots simmering Plots at the same time.  Personally my preference is movies that are serious and stimulating.  So many pots of plot simmering that, actually, you don't know what the truth is in A Most Wanted Man. Lol. Even after you watch the movie, I mean, film, you might feel like i felt.. ___Note: Id say take your time with this one. Be patient with the plot. It's twisty. And intelligent.  _i first saw Phillip Seymour Hoffman in the film 'Capote'. I must say in that film I thought he embodied the character, the character being a Writer. Such a great actor. So sorry he came to a tragic end too soon in real life. His acting lives on in film. Enjoy the film. I mean movie. I mean film. lol. --Bill Curtis_writer
There is no substance in this movie to be thrilled. All we see the lead character''s smoke and drinking habit. There is no grip in the story and ending is confusing.
Fantastic work.  Such a shame it was to be Phillip Seymour Hoffman's last.

So many twist, so many angles, so much deceit.  This was an awesome film that was full of all the attributes the CIA, KGB, BIA, and the likes possess.  This one is sure to have the conspiracy theorist on the edge of their seats.  Great job!

Hoffman was great, as usual. I really enjoyed this movie, although it took me a good 15 minutes to appreciate its multi-layered storyline. Thoughtful, deep, intense... Worth watching.
Excellent acting and writing.
Very enjoyable

I thought Phillip Seymour Hoffman pulled off being a German, while Willem Dafoe did not.  Story was compelling, but left me frustrated at the end.  Not happy with the way the U.S. Intelligence was portrayed.

Good acting but the ending totally sucked. I would not have watched it had I known it had that kind of ending. My husband, however liked the whole thing.

I'm not a fan of most spy stuff, and I have never made it through a Le Carre book because reading it is like reading The Economist, but at least when I read that I learn things that might be relevant to my life.  We made it half way through this movie before swtiching to Hawaii 5-0.  If you are a fan of spy movies and this author, I'm sure this tour of seedy places in Hamburg will delight you.  But I gave up.

Engaging spy flick. Probably more 'realistic' than your typical hero spook movie. Hoffman plays a rather gritty lead with a good supporting cast. Plenty of twists and turns with a well developed plot.
No sex, gore or blood and guts, just a few rough visuals and some very colorful language. Probably not for sensitive ears. The ending is not satisfying, but it does end okay. I haven't researched it, but Hoffman's passing may have affected the end.
I would have rated it 4 1/2 stars due to the ending, but Amazon doesn't let us use half stars. Overall, good watch and recommended.
PS Hoffman was excellent! Great movie ... Watch and enjoy!

This is classic John le Carre, though it keeps the suspense up to the very end. The actors are excellent; Philip Seymour Hoffman obviously stands out but is quite well-supported. The music is great too- I'm as fond of superspies like James Bond as anyone, but le Carr's stories are simply a class apart. This film captures the spirit of his telling.

It's difficult to review this movie objectively due to PSH's passing.  In fact, he looks ill throughout the movie, and that probably wasn't acting.  At any rate, I couldn't shake the fact from my mind as I watched it.  There's one particular scene where he rolls out of bed, his hair is pasted back, and he shakily reaches for a tumbler of whiskey that seemed absolutely real.  Of course, it could his fine acting ability.  And it's only in honor of talent that I managed to give this film 2 stars.

The plot?  Le Carre used to be good at going deep while keeping up the pace in his books.  Since I didn't read the book on which the movie is based, I can only extrapolate from the film adaptation that he's lost that ability.  I quit reading a few books back when the plots became implausible.  This movie starts out suspenseful, then reaches a plateau where only the early momentum kept me watching--only to discover much of the early action turned out to inconsequential.  One central character annoyingly undergoes a completely radical reversal without much justification.

But it was the abrupt ending that astonished me.  All that emotional build up, the anticipation, then it ended like that????

Frankly, I'm surprised at all the positive reviews, some calling this the penultimate spy movie.  To me, you could watch the first half hour or so and the last 10 minutes and not miss anything other than the dissolution/dissipation of yet another great Hollywood actor.

Mr. Hoffman was a great American actor. A most wanted man was NOT a venue through which he could command his artistic sense. It's not that it was too dark, when received on my 5.1 system (Multi-faceted Yamaha receiver, with volume controls available for ALL speakers for adjustment), the sound was ridiculously low in volume. I would have to 'ride the POT' as we used to say, to get a balanced output. If  I left it alone, my wife would look at me in the loud parts and complain that I kept it TOOOOO Loud.
Then there was the whispering in German and English. If I can't follow the story as it is being presented on the screen, I tend to FALL asleep. Consequently, what made the story so good for others was wasted on me.  To make matters worse, I woke up in time to see the denoument of the story; not knowing that I had missed so much that the end looked logical to me. "What happened?", I asked. he had the whole thing wrapped up and then it fell apart I said joyless. My wife explained it to me. I lied to her. I said I would watch it again.

Interesting take on how Foreign authorities deal with terrorist threats and the political backstabbing that Americans do. It is not made clear but the US is not a party to many International treaties , such as the Hague convention, on how prisoners and evidence is handled. When you are one of the most powerful countries in the world, you apparently do not have to play by the rules. Phillip Seymour Hoffman gives an outstanding performance and the ensemble cast is powerfully moving in this tale of justice and injustice.

The movie had a lot of potential, and its cry against injustice is needed in every day and age, but it seemed to only fairly represent one side in the story. Therefore, like so many other movies that make the same mistake, it created a caricature of the establishment-enemy, which certainly stirs up some to anger over injustice, but fails to present any positive solution. As a result, the audience is left only with discouragement and anger, rather than a path to hope and justice.

I listened to the audiobook of this novel not long after it arrived. It is a complex and rich tale, but at times too slow to my liking (though I'm not a Mc-Novel fan, note). It was a fascinating suspenseful plot, all told, and for those who have a mind for world politics, the paradoxes of fighting terrorism, this is a terrific novel, and the movie suited it. It has a very human suspenseful mood to it.
The film richly presented the painful journey of the major characters: Hoffman's intelligence agent character as well as the young, troubled immigrant from the Middle East.
This was a book -- and same for the film -- that would greatly appeal to those who aren't pedestrian about the risks and pitfalls to resisting terrorism and extremism, intelligence services matters, government bureaucratic jealousies and crossed interests, civil security paradoxes, and world politics.
It was a rather engaging film to me, not an action flick by any stretch, but good for suspense and intrigue.
If you wonder why America has a contentious debate going on about helping Muslims by immigration and at their homelands, this might be a good movie for you.

It's a grim night at the movies.

A brilliant spy movie  that asks the question, "How far can one trust a turned agent?" German counter-terrorist officer Gnther Bachmann (Philip Seymour Hoffman) uses traditional Western- or CIA-spycraft--where officers leverage and recruit "agents"--to work up a ladder of Radical Islamic Terrorist financing. He continues successful recruitment, under the increasingly skeptical watch of the German BND and the US CIA. Yet how far can a turned agent be trusted? And when is it time to stop?

Tense and unpredictable plotting, great cinematography, and brilliant acting combine in this memorable movie. To see it as a political statement is to misunderstand espionage. Here we have a moral dilemma and no easy answers. Here, as Philip Seymour Hoffman's character says mid-movie, "is the real world."
Hoffman at what he did best! Stellar supporting cast as well. This movie is a secret gem. Look for Hoffman's delicious subtlety.

John Le Carre is, in my opinion, one of the best fiction writers of the 20 century. Other than the excellent PBS series Smiley's People, I have not seen his work brought to the screen so well as with this movie. In the case of the former, the story was allowed to develop over many hours while in the case of 'A Most Wanted Man' there are only 120 or so minutes to get acquainted with all the characters as well as the plot, which is a challenge. If nothing else, Le Care develops characters - taking you into their minds and exposing their thoughts. This is not easy to do in a movie format.  Le Carre's novels always have the themes of seduction, trust, conflicting loyalties, betrayal (often by those who are supposed to be 'on the same side'), and of course questioning of the importance of each battle in the grand scheme of things. I must admit that I have not read the novel that this movie is based on, but the Le Carre themes and characters are unmistakable.

Many have already written on the plot and basic merits of the movie. I will only add the following in the hopes that others will not be mislead by the low rating as I almost was. The low ratings are mostly from those who expected a James Bond or Mission Impossible style thriller. Thank God this is not one of those. Instead, if you are interested, you will find excellent, nuanced, performances by all the main characters (esp PSH, who I normally do not like), an engaging plot and a typically Le Carre ending. I enjoyed every minute.

Good acting, good story, well laid out.  The story line is well laid out and allows the viewer to follow along and piece together what is going on.  There is information that is held back, so the viewer is begging for just a bit more in anticipation of the next scene of the movie.  The actors do a great job of making you think they are who they portray, Hoffman did very well.  The movie pace is good and while you feel some anxiety to solve the riddle quickly, the movie walks you through the process on pace.  The turns in the story bring in the viewer and cause viewers to mimic the emotions of the characters, pointing to a very good job directing and editing.  All-in-all, I highly recommend this movie.

After this, I never want to Seymour Hoffman. In this movie, he talks a lot, sometimes sitting down, sometimes standing, sometimes in a bar, other times in a car. A Most Wanted Man is a well-acted movie that moves at a stately pace.  If you're looking for layered intrigue, shoot-outs and/or car chases, this is not the movie for you.  Instead, expect a procedural format with a very few twists and a modest amount of character development.  Dialogue is interesting without being dense and, unfortunately, is often overshadowed by the soundtrack.  It feels like this could and should have been more tense, more suspenseful, and it just wasn't.  Not a bad movie, not a great movie.  Overwhelmingly "meh".

I usually do not post reviews but I saw a lot of reviews complaining about the ending and the lack of action so I wanted to set the record straight. This movie was absolutely amazing if you like the style of Le Carre. In every scene and especially the ending you could easily tell that Le Carre wrote this. His barebones, cold style built the tension perfectly. So if you enjoy reading Le Carre and/or you want a realistic spy film watch this, you will love it. Also for all the Hoffman fans out there this is a tour de force for him.

For a favorite actor and author, this was a poor showing. John le Carre apparently lost his touch a long time ago.  This screen adaptation made a marginally entertaining novel worse.  This was not one of Hoffman's better performances.  He seemed to be hanging around the scenes and occasionally making inconsequential statements in an affected accent. The character played well by beautiful Rachel McAdams was preposterous.
Action thriller doesn't describe this movie at all. Actors mumbled the entire time, plot was no existent, and aside from one car crash, no action.

LeCarre wrote the book on which this film is based, and this is LeCarre distilled and, in my opinion, improved in many ways.  A beaten-down but not bowed German spy, who is not allowed to operated in Germany, under the German constitution seizes a chance event to manipulate events to make the world safer in his opinion.  He must face not only the difficulties inherent in trying to convert the illegal arrival of a Chechen immigrant in Hamburg into a major intelligence coup against a different target (If you are not familiar with LeCarre, it helps in watching the beginning to remember that there are two threads that will come together if one is patient), but also the open opposition of many in his own government--for mixed reasons.  American intelligence plays a crucial role in deciding the ultimate outcome.

This is not James Bond.  This is not Jack Ryan or Mission Impossible.  It is a world of constant and inevitable betrayal.  It is a wold of indirection, misdirection, and deep moral ambiguity, much deeper than even those films and tv shows that allow for moral ambiguity in their portrayal of the fight against terrorism.  It has little or no action.  It can be painful watching the betrayals--and a bit unbelievable in the speed at which things happen but there is always that problem with spy novels.  The dialogue is crisp but much is left unsaid and even contrary to the spoken words.  Hoffman and all the actors are very convincing to me.

As opposed to the book on which it is based, it seems fairer to me on the third watching and more direct than the book.  This may seem hard to believe for some, but LeCarre is a most frustrating writer at times.  He captured the Cold War era beautifully but his subsequent books have been swimming against the tide and also erratic.

Highly recommended if you are in the mood.  If not, stay away.  It will only frustrate and irritate you immensely.

While most movies are not as good as the books they are based upon, this does not, in my opinion, apply to John le Carre books; they are good, but the films are better. Phillip Seymour Hoffman does a splendid acting job in this film and the plot and suspense are very good.

A small undercover, unofficial German unit, headed by Hoffman, is trying to discover and prove that a supposedly pacifistic Muslim is giving large amounts of money to terrorists. A larger official German agency does not like Hoffman and is opposed to his plans. Hoffman is working with a female lawyer who represents foreigners seeking asylum in Germany. The person seeking asylum controls ten million euros. The Americans say they support Hoffman, but based on past experience, he does not trust them. The film has a surprise ending.

I believe this movie was Philip Seymour Hoffman's (PSH) last movie before he died. It's VERY gritty, has the look of a documentary. It was filmed in Germany in the winter so looks very grey. He did a good, light German accent but the pace of his speech and the 'forward' sound instead of guttural, as many real German accents are, were still American.

The first problem I have with this movie is it's not compelling. The title makes me think there would be some kind of manhunt, and indeed there is, but it doesn't start until more than 20 minutes into the film. Most modern movies set out the story and introduce the main characters in an exciting way in the first 20 minutes so that you want to see the rest of it. This movie doesn't do that. Then, after a slow beginning, it's not clear why the man was wanted. It goes on and on and on and on with mostly incomprehensible plot lines before I find out that the lawyer (played by Jennifer Garner) is, as PSH's character says, a Leftist social worker. She's protecting some guy who says he's Chechin but has a Russian name, a Russian father, is hiding out with a family whose older woman wears a headscarf so might be Muslim, has a bank account with the bank run by Willem Defoe... The plot is so complex that I lost track and ceased to care.

The worst part might be an Amazon Prime Video problem. The movie simply went to black without any denouement. Was it the end of the movie or was it a video streaming glitch? Who knows? Who cares?

I didn't know anything about this movie going in and had no expectations.  I was really just curious to see Hoffman in his last role.  From the description I had thought it may be some kind of spy thriller along the lines of 24.  That was not the case at all.  This is a powerful drama that moves slowly but steadily through its story.  The story here isn't about action or espionage and that may disappoint some.  The real point of this movie is a look at people.  People who find themselves in a business that is often dark and harrowing.  Hoffman is fantastic (as always) and the rest of the cast does a great job of keeping up.

Definitely sit down and watch this movie with an open mind.  Be prepared to sit quietly, listen closely, and watch attentively.  Don't get hung up on genre conventions or real world politics.  This is a story about characters in a complex world just trying to do the best they can.

An enjoyable and intriguing story set in the follow the money and you'll find the master puppeteer mindset of international intelligence.  ****--- SPOILER Follows ---***  Philip Seymour Hoffman plays a German Intelligence Officer who has found a political refugee who appears to have terrorist connections.  With both the German and American intelligence agencies determined to immediately stamp out terrorism whenever and wherever it appears Philip Hoffman's character is taking a longer point of view and asks '...if this is a terrorist then who is funding and him and who is directing the activities...'.  It is this intrigue, of whether to bring in the suspect now and attempt to force information from him or to attempt a longer term approach in hopes of getting more valuable information, that drives this enjoyable story.

Philip Seymour Hoffman delivers yet one more exceptional performance in a film that doesn't quite manage to find a way to honor it. There is simply not enough intrigue in a story about a man most wanted, certainly, but whose crimes are completely unknown to us (if they exist at all). Quite a lot of time is spent in this admittedly well-shot and consummately acted 'thriller' trying to parse out just exactly what the titular wanted man did to warrant such a manhunt as we're forced to sit through. A cold, detached manhunt, mind you, in which most of the would-be spies time is spent smoking, muttering, and listening in on rather large heaphones. I'm not advocating for a Bourne-esque thrill ride--there is certainly a place for quiet, meditative spy films (Le Carre's own Tinker Tailor Solider Spy managed to enthrall without ladeling on too many shoot outs)--but it would have been nice to have some respite from the cold, some reason to keep watching. As it is, we watch for Hoffman, who can't save the film from the drugery of its world, the pointlessness of its maddening tinkering, watching, waiting, slumbering on.

Let me help you understand. A fine performance by the late Mssr. Hoffman with strong supporting work from Ms. McAdams. Sadly the puerile ending mars what might have been. For those of you familiar with Comrade Le Carre's work, the America-as-Rome boogeyman makes yet another tired appearance. Pity the poor fellow traveller, Carre, who just can't seem to come to grips with "Great" Britain's loss of power. Confining himself in ever smaller circles of ham-fisted Columbia killing, we end up with A Most Unwanted Ending. If you find enjoyment in warmed over tropes of, shall I repeat myself, the ills of Roman power escaping safe Grecian hands, this then is the film (whoops, Riefenstahlapalooza) for you. Snore. Take your pinky ringed poofery and stick it where you clearly find enjoyment Mr. Le Carre. Must dash, Pericles on the Thames is about to sermonize....again.

In my opinion, if you can't do a book justice, then don't try to make the movie.  This movie suffers from all the problems of character development that so many movies do.  John LeCarre's strength is character development and it helps the reader understand the character's motivations.  None of that exists in this movie of paper thin characters and it results in awkward scenes where the characters seemingly don't know to look or what to say.  Whoever said that this was Philip Seymour Hoffman's finest performance . . . well, I'll leave out the insult and say his poor performance is probably not his fault, considering the poorly written script.  In essence, this story, as with most of John LeCarre's books, are better off left alone by movie makers unless they are willing to make it into a mini-series.  That way, the richness of the dialogue and character development can pull the observer into the world John LeCarre creates.

This movie has been maligned and misunderstood by far too many reviewers who are not accustomed to the calculated complexity and taut, steady pacing of John le Carr, an acknowledged master of espionage thrillers focused on people and politics rather than explosions and weaponry. There are no car chases, no dramatic mass murders, no amazing special effects, just a believably intricate story of betrayal inspired by the real double-dealings of our own clandestine services. Hoffman's performance is one of flawless understatement, creating a genuine three-dimensional person on screen. It is a thoughtful and thought-provoking thriller about layers of betrayal, recommended only for intelligent viewers willing to grapple with the complexities of covert operations as actually carried out rather than splashy cartoon spy dramas. James Bond it is not. Le Carr it is.

I like spy movies and I like John LeCarre.  His stories tend to "build" with time, so it takes a little while for the ball to start rolling.  It is about the same pace as "A Perfect Spy."  It takes a while, but you get there in the end.  Phillip Seymour Hoffman turns in an excellent performance.  You almost believe that he really is German!  It is not a bad way to spend a couple of hours, but if your looking for "Bourne" type action, this is not for you.  It is more cerebral in its approach, and probably closer to real life.  "Bourne" is a lot more crash, bang and wallop.  I can recommend this for good early evening entertainment.

Pretty good adaptation of Le Carre's novel and probably a good representation of the seedy and dubious nature of the espionage world.  Phillip Seymour Hoffman is excellent and the supporting cast is very good.  This movie is slower than what many may be able to tolerate these days but it is a spy movie in the vein of "The Spy Who Came in from the Cold":  No winners, no gadgets, no happy ending, no glamour, just the eternal struggle between the pawns who believe they are doing good and the psychopaths who run the game.  I found it entertaining and thought provoking with solid performances. A classic espionage noir film.

The movie is based on a novel by the spy-thriller writer John le Carr that is very relevant to our time. Even better than the story is the contribution of Phillip Seymour Hoffman as Gnther Bachmann, pseudo freelance spymaster. Every time I see a Phillip Seymour Hoffman film I realize what a great talent we lost. He was so convincing in his characters and this film is testimony to that fact. A Most Wanted Man has an excellent pace and keeps things interesting with a minimum of crashing and banging about. The chases and fights that we do see are believable and realistic. The film ends the story on an inconclusive note, but I think that's the point. PSH aside, Rachel MacAdams was very good in her role as the vulnerable, out-of-her-league lawyer Annabel Richter, and Willem DaFoe overcame his distracting familiarity with a convincing performance of the ber-rich German banker Tommy Brue. The only reason I didn't give it a fifth star is the feeling of dissatisfaction resulting from the troubled ending - wondering what the heck Gnther Bachmann is going to do now and whether the wrongs can ever be mitigated. They certainly can't be righted.

While Phillip Seymour Hoffman (RIP) is well equipped to handle this role; the movie is like a pit of quicksand.  There is never a firm footing; we rarely understand the premise of what is trying to be accomplished by the principals.  Finally given something at the end of the film that we can hope for; we are left back in our quicksand pit.  Rachel McAdams plays a reasonable part in this film, but given that it is supposed to be post 9/11 Hamburg, Germany, the actors speaking poorly German accented English adds little to our ability to have empathy for their characters.

This would be a two star rating, however it was PSH on the screen that gives this a third star simply because we will miss his talent.

This was such a plodding dark morose (bad?) film I gave up watching it in one sitting; I watched 1/2 the first night; it WAS at the 1/2 way point by the time I had enough; I watched the other 1/2 the next night. The ONLY reason I went back at all to watch the second night (or went as far as I did the first night) was Phillip Seymour Hoffman. I lament his passing. I LAMENT that this had to be his last film!!! In retrospect one can only wonder if the stark dark moroseness of this film, of the story-line! Which, I sadly don't think is untrue as a story-line about an intelligence operation, the operatives and about the USA attempt at worldwide intelligence hegemony. One can only wonder if this dark, morose, crappy-but-real-perhaps, story/film didn't feed into his own personal demons/needs and might have helped push the edge: of care, concern, etc. If you watch this film YOU will want an escape: trust me! [All this said I am aware of the vast timing difference(s) between making a film, its editing, promotion, release, and the time of his passing, etc. I leave it to some art student to see if there is any time-line-connection in the events of his life in regards the feelings I share here and wonder about.]  ALL THIS SAID: Mr. Hoffman plays the part well, OUTSTANDING!  BUT Mr. Hoffman and the ensemble cast CAN NOT  turns a pigs ear into a silk purse.  Unless you like, LIKE, Phillip Seymour Hoffman: don't watch this film.

This is not meant to be a thriller in the vein of James Bond or Jason Bourne. The movie is adapted from the novel by the same name written by John Le Carre--an author known for subtle, realistic, spy fiction.  It's not an action movie, and that may turn off many viewers. However, for those will to be patient and pay attention to details, A Most Wanted Man is definitely worth the time.  I have no connection to the intelligence community, but if I had to guess, I'd say real intelligence services operate much more like those imagined by Le Carre than the action-packed, over-gadgeted MI6 of Ian Fleming or the ultraviolent CIA of Robert Ludlum.

As the last scene closes, with Seymour Phillip Hoffman shuffling off scene, my heart felt a strong tug. This was one of his last movies, and the scene seemed to be portentous. Others here  have given excellent summaries of the plot, so I will stick to the masterful acting of everyone in the cast. Hoffman is brilliant, conveying wide ranging emotions, subtle and not-so character quirks; DaFoe is an actor at the top of his game, a perfect foil; Rachel McAdams (now starring in HBO's True Detective) is compelling, as is Robin Wright.

Philip Seymour Hoffman was exceptional as the German Case Officer attempting to penetrate and monitor the Muslim community in Hamburg for possible terrorist cells as part of a special unit in German Intelligence that operated on the edge, and often beyond it, of constitutional legality to build his networks. Rumpled, a chain smoker, overweight, he is  the antithesis of popular notions of intelligence operatives who are frequently portrayed as handsome, supremely confident with extraordinary physical endurance and strength.  Despite his everyman appearance he is a shrewd judge of character, as case officers who run sources must be, and possesses a moral code that is revealed as the movie proceeds and for me was the most interesting facet of his persona.  The film takes a deliberate approach to the subject allowing its principle characters to be revealed as much more than the usual Hollywood caricatures this genre of film habitually trots out giving time for the viewer to better appreciate their motivations and the difficult circumstances they find themselves in. Phillip Seymour Hoffman's hard edged empathy is frequently on display.  Hamburg serves as an excellent setting for the story to evolve as Hoffman and his team attempt to achieve their result while others in the German Government and the CIA are watching and waiting.  Not only an exceptional film but a reminder of what film lovers lost in  Mr. Hoffman's tragic death. Please see it.

For the first time in about forever I am really struggling with this review.  The movie was tense, gritty, well written and well acted, but I had difficulty focusing on the content of the movie itself because of its star:  Phillip Seymour Hoffman.  In every scene and in every action or bit of business that involved the character played by Mr. Hoffman, I was looking for signs of the addictions that eventually took his life.  I parked my rating squarely in the middle of the road as I do not recall anything of a significant negative nature; conversely and due to my distraction with Hoffman I do not recall anything of a significant positive nature either.  If/when I watch it again I may be revising this post.

I was wondering wtf was the problem with this movie, until I started reading reviews and discovered that it's an adaptation of a Le Carre novel or book. I realize this was not one of his cold war novels, but still, the feel of this is all wrong, and the attempt I think was to use a contemporary subject (terrorism) in a format of a cold war spy plot. Sorry, does not fly. Along with many other bad choices made here, this underlying attempt to translate an entirely different period into modern terms has the usual effect: an off key feel to everything. Also while I admire some of the work of PS Hoffman, this is not one of his better performances. Everyone is miscast and poorly directed. Each character is worse than the last. Willem Dafoe is abominable. Not good.

Slow moving movie about an anti-terrorist spy group tracking down a terrorist.  This was a very serious movie with some excellent acting.  Philip Seymour Hoffman (as Gunther Bachmann, head of the anti-terrorism group) was fantastic.  Rachel McAdams (as Annabel Richter a human rights lawyer),  Willem Dafoe (as Tommy Brue, a banker) and Nina Hoss (as Erna Frey, second in command of the anti-terrorism group) were all great in their roles.

I felt that the movie wanted to be profound and relevant, however the story fell a little flat to me.  Maybe this was because the characters in the movie were a lot more interesting to me than the movie plot.  All of the main characters had various issues mainly centering around the theme of loneliness and redemption that I wanted more of their stories than I did of the movie plot.

Overall, well worth watching especially if you are a fan of Philip Seymour Hoffman, Rachel McAdams, Willem Dafoe or Nina Hoss.

Once again Mr. Hoffman captures the essence of his character [Gunter Bachmann] and defines the roll.  This movie exposes the huge gulf between law enforcement and the intelligence community.  Acquiring Intelligence in real time requires a surgical approach with a "scalpel", whereas law enforcement brings a "sledge hammer"and a "chain saw" to the problem.  They could care less about the collateral damage they cause to innocent persons who have risked their lives to help us.  John le Carre understands this "gulf" too well and brings it to life in this provocative cerebral thriller. Philip Seymour Hoffman is brilliant and will be missed by millions of movie goers around the world.  A great "final curtain" call for
Mr. Hoffman. Rest in peace Philip.

The main character Issa is a Muslim terrorist who has been tortured by the Russians and Turks and escaped to Germany seeking asylum. For some reason, the Germans believe he is innocent without checking the facts and help him get asylum. He is an heir to a fortune left by his father, a horrible Christian Russian who raped an innocent 15 years old Muslim girl and so Issa was born. Issa claims the money but then says he doesn't want it because 'it is dirty money' and wants to give it all to Muslim charities (All Muslims are so good and charitable, yeah right)  Enter another ". Enter another "noble" Muslim man Abdulla who organizes charities and says that even though the poor Muslims are suffering in Palestine, Iraq and Afghanistan, they are charitable people and should not engage in terrorism. Correction; Muslim in all other 'free' Muslim countries like Iran, Yemen, Syria etc suffer even more and this is because of their backwards religion whose main teachings are murder, repression, destruction and inferiority of women and they DEFINITELY engage in non-stop violence and terrorism all over the world.
I don't want to give away the whole dull idiotic story, but suffice to say it is so absurd and pro-Muslim, anti-American and anti-Christian that it is plain pathetic.

This film was badly panned, and I must confess I do and I don't understand why. Perhaps the weakest aspect of the film was what plagues all productions of Le Carre's books - the loss of the rich detail that contributes to the pleasure of reading the text. But that's how book adaptations go. Although I had read the book, I nonetheless mostly enjoyed the movie. Perhaps the film needed to be longer - two hours might just have done it. The film seems to skip from highlight to essential point, the advantage being the plot's line never lost tempo. The bad with the good. I give it three stars, wanted to give it four, but just could not. Sadly, Hoffman's last movie.

Smart spy drama set in Hamburg

A Most Wanted Man offers Seymour Hoffman and Willem Defoe both chances to shine in this international thriller.  Nobody writes 'em like LeCarre, except maybe Tom Clancy

Hoffman plays the leader of a German antiterrorism group while Defoe is a banker who has inherited from his father, big problems in the form of international money laundering mainly from the Russian military.

Along comes Ivan "Issa" (his Islamic name) Karpov, son of said Russian military man and a Chechan woman raped by the man, trying to immigrate to Germany in Hamburg.  Issa stands to inherit millions of Euros from his father.

This is a well acted and played out movie.  Even passing the two hour mark my hamster sized attention span managed to enjoy this flick.
Don't waste your time on this movie. Bad, Bad, BAD! It builds and builds, only to dump you off at a very unsatisfying ending. Pfffft.

A most wanted man is extremely watchable because it was not only based on a John Le Carre novel but also it was  the last memorable performances by Philip Seymour Hoffman. As Gunther, the German spy who works relentlessly trying to stop another 9/11.
The impressive cast includes William Defoe as a banker and Rachel Mcadams an activist lawyer who wants to help a Chechen immigrant collect an inheritance. However he is suspected of terrorism and questions arise about his true intentions and his inheritance. The immigrant is used as a bait to bust a network of terrorist financing by intelligence agencies.
This film unravels slowly but Hoffman is  as always amazing, as a weary and cynical spy, trying his best to avoid a terrorist attack but the role is such that he cannot do much to save it from mediocrity.
Boring.  Hard to follow.
Just so so

Excellent spy story. Of course, it's by John LeCarre, so one expects it to be first-rate. Hoffman is in his last role before his untimely death, but it's one of his best portrayals. He is very convincing and plays the part to the hilt. His incessant chain smoking, sips of whiskey and coffee with occasional food tells the story of a man consumed by his role and position as the head of the German spy organization focused to protect Germany from another attack by extremists.
The setting for this film is perfect... seemingly cold, damp and cloudy Germany. Hamburg and Berlin.
(Spoiler, sort of, Alert.)
While the ending is a surprise, afterwards one realizes it is not as much of a surprise as experienced. Everyone is out for their own glory at any cost. Bachmann (Hoffman) was used and abused. No one seemingly cared about his real objective in this matter. His superiors, from the moment they appeared in the story, never wanted to share in the success and never cared about the longer-term strategy which Sullivan (Robin Wright) as the CIA liaison identified early on: to save the world. Personal glory was the focus.
Which country is this? Apparently this film had no dialect coach. Distracting when the actors' accents vary from scene to scene. Gave up after an hour.

Hoffman's performance was stellar, as was the rest of the cast, particularly W. DaFoe and Rachel McAdams. It's well worth a watch, even more than once, but not really a "go-to" movie. The reasons why are pace and storyline. A few reviewers labeled it as "fast-paced" but it's quite the opposite - 2 full hours of interesting yet extremely slowly-evolving drama. As for the storyline, I only mention it because 3/4 of the way through I still had no freaking clue what was going on and had to Wikipedia the plot (somewhat hard to do without getting to far and ruining the rest of the movie). It worked, though, and was able to enjoy the ending much better.

A note on Hoffman: it's a terrible shame this was his last major role. I don't know how actors who are able to morph so deeply into their characters are able to cope in a positive way with "real life." I don't know if the SAG offers support for their members in this regard, but to me it seems like a no-brainer that it's either desperately needed or in dire need of improvement.

Not much of a review to write here as we hardly could get through the movie. Perhaps we will return but on our first attempt it was really difficult to follow. I like Hoffman in almost everything I've seen him in but this movie just did not pan out for us.

Let"s face it, A MOST WANTED MAN is basically a Cold War thriller updated to the post 9/11 era.  Only this time the enemies are not the Soviets or the CIA, but Islamic terrorists.  But then what else would one expect from the pen of John le Carr?

In its clichd way, the film is a good example of the genre, building up suspense gradually until the dnouement when Gunther (Philip Seymour Hoffman) realizes that all his plans have gone awry.  Granted, the action is not without its stereotypes (western filmmakers can never seem to understand the Islamic form of prayer, especially the five-times-a-day worshiping ritual, while the general view expressed by the Europeans is that most members of the Islamic faith are suspect, even if they lead perfectly normal lives).  On the other hand, the direction is pleasantly low-key, with plenty of atmosphere placed on the dank, muddy-colored streets of Hamburg.

In the end A MOST WANTED MAN shows nobody actually winning the battle - or should it be struggle - to "make the world a safer place."  The US Embassy (personified by a sour-faced Robin Wright) are shown to be entirely self-interested, more concerned with maintain the country's status as the world's sole superpower rather than worrying about individual people.  Gunther tries to show his humanity, but in the end even he reduces the people whom he deals with to ciphers.

Closest thing to real life I have watched to real life. The movie included chase scenes, investigation, turning informants like every other movie but it delved into the complexity of clandestine operations strengths & weaknesses. Overall a very interesting movie with an ending that, although predictable,  was also very good.  Phillip Hoffman was amazing in his role.

There are all manner of spy flicks out there with wildly different approaches and flavors. For my dollar this rang truer than most I've seen and was made much better that others as well.

Here's the scoop. Set in Hamburg, Germany, a fugitive Muslim enters the country illegally. An intelligence unit has their eye on him thinking he might be a terrorist. It turns out he might lead them to an even bigger fish but the waters start to roil as other intelligence networks want to get involved.

This was based on a John Le Carre' novel and it reads like the real thing. This is not slick Hollywood stuff. Some might take issue with the fact that four of the leading German roles are played by American actors, but, were those roles populated by German actors, most simply would not go to see it. Anyway....first is Phillip Seymour Hoffman. What a character. He drinks too much. Smokes too much and hot-boxes his cigarettes. But he's great at what he does and manages to get what he wants from people. He's able to tell them how screwed they are and they nearly thank him for it. Robin Wright plays a CIA operative. She's cold and calculating in here discussions with Hoffman. Rachel McAdams plays a Lawyer trying to get legal status for the Muslim. Willem Dafoe plays a wealthy banker. This is a good cast once you bypass the so-so accents.

The story is believable in the same way "The Spy Who Came in From the Cold" is believable. It's intelligence gathering that turns into manipulation once the information is in hand. There is a casual frankness to the dialogue. Those in the know speak to each anther in very matter of fact terms while the subject matter is of the utmost importance. It threw me a bit at first before I realized that's how these people operate. They all know what is going on so why beat around the bushes?

Acting, directing, editing, music all come together in a satisfying whole. Director Anton Corbijn showed the same subtle deftness in his approach here as he did in "The American." This might not be everyone's cup of tea but I found it to be one of the best spy films I've ever seen.

This film is one of Phillip Seymour Hoffman's last films, and it is not a disappointment. His acting is one of the top performances I have seen. He Gunther Bacchman, a German in the high stakes spy game. He has been relegated to Hamburg after a disaster in Istanbul. Hamburg if you remember was the staging grounds for the Saudis who planned 9/11. Bachmann and his team have the Islamic group to follow. They have a highly placed Muslim leader they think is siphoning off funds from charities for other works.

A Russian/Chechnian man named Issa Karpov, played by Grigoriy Dobrygin, arrives in Hamburg, in a most unorthodox manner. Bacchman wants to follow him, other groups in the spy business want him arrested. A truce of sorts is made. So the follow game begins. A banker, played by Willem Dafoe, becomes involved, as does a human rights activist named Annabel Richter played by Rachel McAdams. The other important player is Robin Wright, with dyed black hair that does her no justice, a CIA operative.

So with all of these players, a cat and mouse game begins. This film is from a book by John Le Carre, so that every secret can collapse the house of cards that Bachmann needs to stay upright. As with all of Le Carre's novels, often much is not as it seems.

We knew that the loss of Phillip Seymour Hoffman, would be great, and this film is a testament to his acting.

This movie has superb acting, interesting settings, and intriguing characters, but is DULL.

Partly, it's the plot, which is one-dimensional and telegraphs all punches.  The epigraph--the words you see right at the beginning--tells you everything: in Hamburg, inter-departmental rivalry defeated any chance the 9/11 plotters would be stopped.  Same again, same here.  There is no tension, no suspense, just a lot of yawn-inducing waiting for something to happen.

Partly it's the lack of suspense, which is made worse by the shaky handheld camera work throughout.  Handheld is fine if you have a Jason Bourne movie in which cars are speeding around and crashing all the time, punctuated by brief bouts of hand-to-hand ninja combat.  Not here.  Shaky-Cam while watching people in a gloomy office who are just sitting there watching computers is dull and pointless.

Partly it's the writing, which is cryptic and pretentious, but not illuminating.  This may result from the novel.  I gave up reading Le Carre some time ago because of its endless ponderous existential angst.  (Angst over nothing, I might add.  Le Carre seems to have angst in his pants.)

But mostly it's the direction and editing.  If  this movie were half as long it would be twice as good--but it still not very good.  The directing is atrocious.  The very fine actors are left with nothing much to do, and look rightly embarrassed.

Pity that Philip Seymour Hoffman's last movie is such a stiff.  He looks terrific--bloated, washed-up, chain-smoking, pasty, hopeless; but it doesn't help.

Two last notes.

1. What's with the accents?  Hoffman's pseudo-German accent is out of nowhere.  Many of the actors in the film are German, and of course their English has the usual soft consonants and clipped vowels.  Rachel McAdams does pretty well with this, but Hoffman's accent is simply muddy.

(Don't get me started on Hollywood's chronic use of English-speaking actors speaking English with an "accent" to indicate they are speaking German.)

2. And what's with Robin Wright's hair??????  This is a fairly high production movie.  Couldn't they afford a good tinting job, instead of the shoepolish black that Wright has?  Or at least a decent wig?

A Most Wanted Man (2014) is a film based on a novel by the same name written by John le Carre, who is a British author known for intelligent espionage novels.  The film has a very intricate plot and is the opposite of films categorized as action-spy, such as the famous James Bond franchise.  The only other film that comes to my mind and is similar in nature to A Most Wanted Man is The Lives of Others (2007).  Interestingly, both films happen to be German productions.  In terms of atmosphere and intrigue, the film is just like any other film based on the writings of le Carre.  So if you liked: Tinker Taylor Soldier Spy (2011), or the Spy Who Came in from the Cold (1966) than you should not disappointed with the last of the films featuring Phillip Seymour Hoffman.

The setting of the film takes place after September 11, 2001 in Hamburg, Germany.  A German and American internal security agencies take avid interest in a homeless and very religious Muslim Russian-Chechen refugee, who one day shows up on the streets of Hamburg asking around for an information on a wealthy and influential German banker (played by Willem Dafoe).  The German "ghost-like" security cell is led by Gunther Bachmann (played by P.S. Hoffman), and his loyal crew of young employees who are savvy in the art of tech-spying and psychological warfare.  Gunther himself is a master at playing mind-games, and his capability to analyze and control people are highly valued by even the American compatriots...

SPOILER ALERT !!!

My question is...did Gunther know about the "others" and willingly compromised his own mission, or was he observed by the "others" and he did not know about the planned "kidnapping" by the rival agency, or maybe he was sold by his female coworker when he gave her that last look before he went inside the car??? I am interested to know how others interpreted the ending.

A Most Wanted Man, 2014 film

It begins by saying interdepartmental rivalries and intelligence failures prevented the discovery of the 9/11 attacks. Hamburg is now a city on high alert. It shows a man answering a cell phone. A man swims ashore and hides among parked cars. Elsewhere a man speaks to an assembly. Surveillance has recognized a man. They will search for him. Men leave a mosque. Note the passage of a message via a micro SD chip. Next he visits a source. Gunther talks to an official about his operation. Issa helps a woman and gets a meal. Gunther wants more time to watch the suspect. Issa is a member of Jihadists who want to make contact with a banker. He is given 3 days to continue. Elsewhere there is a meeting at an apartment, a man seeks asylum. The lawyer visits a banker about an account number.

The banker looks up old bank records and calls the lawyer. [Note the subtle language.] Gunther talks to Tommy about a job. Later Tommy meets Issa about a letter. [They are under surveillance.] Tommy talks to Gunther, who talks to an American agent. Have a nice day. A student talks to Gunther about his job. Theres no going back for any of us. The banker talks to Issas lawyer, she warns Issa to remove his beard and move to a new place. Issa spots a tail! Then he and Annabelle duck into a club to escape. Gunther explains what he knows about a shipping company, and why he wants to wait. A stranger talks to Annabelle on the street! They know about her. Can I go now? Gunther explains her status. There is a difference between them and us. Who is the solution? [Note the glass block walls for lighting.]

Gunther talks to Annabelle again. Is Issa innocent? She is released and visits Issa. Some men install equipment in that empty apartment. Look at him. Annabelle is advised not to go home because others are looking for her. Annabelle talks to Issa. [They are being watched.] What does Issa want? Annabelle brings news. The banker is given an assignment. He will donate money to Chechnya via a trusted religious man. Issa is questioned by Dr. Abdullah, who accepts the gift. Gunther explains his actions to a board. And what he has planned. Will this make the world a safer place? Issa is given asylum. Dr. Abdullah changes the name of one recipient. [Note the tone of his voice.] Then something goes very wrong! Gunther drives away. [And so it ends.]

This is based on a book by John Le Carr, who was one of the Executive Producers. This was filmed in Hamburg and shows the building styles, one advantage of this movie (once you sit through this movie). I didn't read the book and don't plan to read it; was the book better than this movie? I hope so, or Le Carr needs to plot better stories. This seems to drag on, you keep hoping it will get better, but it doesnt. There is a deus ex machina ending that negates the previous two hours. Whos in charge here? Are those private banks possible in America? Who regulates them? John Le Carr says this story is about extra-ordinary renditions, which deprive people of their natural rights. This movie runs on too long. I think his earlier novels from the 1960s were better. This provides examples of operations that can affect you.

A spy thriller that is deliberately paced - you will either find it boring, or you will enjoy the delicious slow-burn tension that pervades the film. I, for one, loved it. This is a terrific spy game. The cast is great, especially Phillip Seymour Hoffman as a shrewd, dedicated yet world-weary operative. The craftsmanship of this film is breathtaking. The same guy who directed A Most Wanted Man directed the American - another spy thriller that got mixed reactions which I happen to love.

If you're looking for a drama that is deep, pensive, slow, pondering and meticulously crafted this is it.  It has a very European feel to it, not just because it is filmed in Europe but from the flavor of the filming.  It was very reminiscent of a Roman Polanski film.  The director is Dutch and he definitely studied Polanski's work.  Phillip Seymour Hoffman is, as usual, brilliant but you can tell that there are a ton of alcohol and drug references mixed in with a few too many super tall and skinny pretty supermodel types -- I couldn't help but think that I was getting a glimpse at the world of Hoffman towards the end.

To me, it was a depressing hardboiled character study into the seedy world of espionage.  If you like those kinds of movies, go for it.

I really wanted to like this film going in - I am a big fan of Phillip Seymour Hoffman. This film has some other well known actors too, and some less well known ones. Hoffman nails his character, similar to his Charlie Wilson's War character. And Robin Wright is mesmerizing. Some of the supporting work is less strong, and while the plot is fairly straight forward - which is good - the final execution and resolution is a little anti-climatic. It has good ambiance and is enjoyable overall.
