From the novel by John Le Carre's novel `A Most Wanted Man' - we get one of the last films from Philip Seymour Hoffman. We have a refugee arriving in the German port of Hamburg. He is half Chechyan and half Russian and has suffered some full on torture. He also has a claim to a mountain of money that has been bequeathed to him by his father. A man he had little time or love for - he is also a convert to Islam.

This arouses the interest of both the German and US governments. With funds flowing to terrorist organisations they want to ensure that he is not going to be a conduit for more of the same. Hoffman plays a counter terrorism officer Gnther Bachman and he has a team of agents who excel at playing the players in what turns out to be a classic game of cat and mouse.

This is an extremely well made film with a brilliant supporting cast that includes the incomparable Willem Dafoe, Daniel Brhl and Robin Wright. There is also a part for one of my fave Germans Kostja Ullmann (`Summer Storm'). This is a production where everyone gives of their best in a story that is at first glance simple, but gets wrapped in a web of deceit and shifting alliances - it is a great testament to the rare ability that Hoffman had and a film that is easy to recommend.

As far as spy movies are concerned, I'll watch the occasional film with the, alas, all too familiar, fiery conflagrations, brutal hand-to-hand fights, exotic temptresses, hip repartee delivered over martinis, and seemingly superhuman derring-do from the hero, and sometimes the villain. But I much prefer the kind of Le Carre-esque story of the kind we get in A Most Wanted Man: low-keyed and character driven, focusing on spycraft mechanics. And AMWM does it as well as anything this side of The Spy Who Came in From the Cold. In this, his penultimate film, Phillip Seymour Hoffman does a brilliant job as the frazzled, low-level bureaucrat/spymaster. He's given stellar support from the rest of the cast, and there's also the sinister, unglamorous Hamburg backdrop. AMWM is one of the more intelligent espionage thrillers I've seen in a while, and thus a strong recommendation.

Philip Seymour Hoffman played this kind of part really well - the frustrated character in a relatively unglamorous position being asked to do the seemingly impossible with bureaucratic obstacles unnecessarily constraining his efforts.  How like life.  Philip, we miss you.
Wonderful movie!

The story of A Most Wanted Man centers on the activities of a German team of espionage specialists pursuing in Hamburg a man named Issa Karpov (Grigoriy Dobrygin), suspected of being a terrorist. Led by a hard-nosed German intelligent agent Gnther Bachmann (Philip Seymour Hoffman), the officially non-existent team tracks the man, who contacts with a lawyer Annabel Richter (Rachel McAdams).

Now Gnther, a disgraced agent, wants a bigger catch, while other people tracking down the man, seem to think differently, like a shrewd CIA officer Martha Sullivan (Robin Wright) and slippery OPC chief Dieter Mohr (Rainer Bock).

Based on a John le Carr book, A Most Wanted Man aims for realism, which is not a bad thing. The film is not about action set-pieces and shootouts, but real people and murky morals. Again, that is not a bad thing, but rock artist photographer turned director Anton Corbijn ("The American") seems more interested in visuals.

With so much attention paid to each characters traits (but not to storytelling which tends to be slow), the film works better as a character study of Gnther Bachmann than as a thriller. Philip Seymour Hoffman is as great as ever, but it must be said that he doesnt look like a German intelligence agent, especially when he speaks in English. Rachel McAdams fares worse, with Nina Hoss, a real German beside her.

The first place I turn to in the newspaper is the sports page so I would be the last person to quiz on International affairs.  If you asked me to distinguish between the Taliban and Al Qaeda you'd be met with a blank stare.  I ventured into this film on the recommendation of a friend hoping for the best.  Considering I'm not a big fan of espionage thrillers I liked the film a lot.  The plot plays like an intricate chess game.  A Russian-Chechen with Islamic sympathies washes ashore in Hamburg and draws the attention of a lot of interested parties.  Who are the players and who's being played?  The German intelligence officer (Philip Seymour Hoffman)? The civil rights lawyer (Rachel  McAdams)? The banker who's been laundering Russian money (Willem Dafoe)?  The American attach (Robin Wright)?  You'll have fun sorting out this cat-and-mouse game and savor the performances none more than Hoffman in his final starring role.  Slovenly looking and drinking and smoking himself into near oblivion Hoffman's Gunther Bachmann projects the assuredness of a chess master in this game of intrigue.  The denouement here falls into the wow category.  Close attention has to be paid but the film works on its own terms.
I just love Phillip Seymour Hoffman.  It kept  my attention during a very uncomfortable flight!!

The most interesting take-away raised by the film is how are governments supposed to protect us when they put most of their efforts into turf wars and bureaucratic wrangling? The Americans come out very badly in this story, wanting to wield a hammer when a needle is what is necessary, and Hoffman's German bosses are much too eager to accommodate them. I can't say more for fear of giving up the plot twists.

First off, let me say that if you are the sort of person who is constantly asking your significant other "can you explain to me what is going on" this is not the movie for you. If you enjoy films that require you to think, that assume you understand from a few clues and visuals what is going on, this is the movie for you. An outstanding cast creates a compelling and suspenseful film with almost no violence. Phillip Seymour Hoffman plays the head of a small, secret German anti-terror unit. The unit detects a Chechen refugee illegally entering Hamburg and begins to track his movements, to determine if he is truly a refugee or a terrorist with a mission. At the same time, the unit is actively investigating a popular moderate Islamic cleric, convinced but unable to prove he is siphoning money from his various charities to fund terrorist activities. Hoffman's goal with both men is not arrests, but using them to find the bigger fish. However, he must combat other German police services and the CIA, whose only goal is to make a splashy arrest. All the actors manage to create very complex characters, especially Willem Dafoe as a private banker, and Robin Wright as the CIA liason. Hoffman is nothing short of superb, and this is one of the best adaptations yet of a Le Carre novel.

Philip Seymour Hoffman is fantastic, just as he was in everything.  Sadly, the movie is not.  It's very slow going, and maybe a bit depressing, too.  It's worth seeing, anyway, since it was one of Hoffman's final performances.

Note: Even though I will attempt to write around spoilers, one may leak into this review.

"A Most Wanted Man" is not the film I expected to see. Promotions touted it as a "tense spy thriller with an unexpected ending." It's that ending that is so bothersome. I fully expected Hoffman to work in counter-intelligence and be that pusher in the center of the "unexpected." Let's just say that the term counter-intelligence goes too far. Hoffman, indeed, goes too far, but (spoiler) not in the way one would think.

Hoffman plays the head of a little spy agency based in Hamburg. While his acting may be intense here and there--but not that much. His acting was neither impressive prize worthy. In fact, his acting was ho-hum, how much am I getting paid for this role? type. Oh yes, there were two really big moments: both times when he lit a cigarette downwind. He had to bend over and stretch his body to prevent the wind from blowing out his light. Not a nail-biting moment.

If I seem to be poking fun at Mr. Hoffman's acting, you must know that I respect his real acting, but this movie doesn't exemplify it. As for other actors, they lend credence to "A Most Wanted Man" as a serious thriller/spy film. Rachel McAdams deserves most praise as the illegal immigrant's attorney, while Willem Dafoe turns in a respectful performance as the banker in charge of the suspected terrorist's huge money supply. Terrorist, immigrant--that's the initial question for the little spy agency and the government of Germany at the beginning. Once the immigrant's identity has been established, focus turns on the Muslim cleric to whom he seeks to give money. The actor playing the Chechen immigrant shows little sign of his acting chops.

The more powerful agencies give free rein to Hoffman's agency in locating the immigrant and following his movements. They also latch on to the attorney. By the end all hands are on deck, so to speak, and all truths are out. And it's not what the viewer has come to expect.

The movie is watchable, but expect no awards, even if this was Hoffman's last full acting gig. There is no sense of urgency or thrill or even danger. The action just plods along, teasing that imminent danger is ahead, but when it comes, what? That was it?

A superbly acted film. Apparently the last film before Phillip Seymour Hoffman committed suicide or over-dosed on drugs. I first became aware of his dynamic and forceful acting talent in the film: The Talented Mr. Ripley. A friend of a man killed brutally by the protagonist, excellently played by Matt Damon as a believable sociopathic guy, Hoffman was aggressively pushing against the paradigm that who the police thought was a suspicious character, was in fact, the killer. The cast included Jude Law, of course, and Gwenneth Paltrow as exasperated participants in a bloody game. Seymour Hoffman in "A Most Wanted Man" is relentless as a spy of a special unit in the German Government. This unit was outside the normal intelligence services, part Counter Intelligence, part Operational Intelligence, all of the German bureaucrats acting under the cloud that they had allowed three Al-Qaeda terrorists to plan & operate inside Germany prior to the September 11, 2001 attack on the United States. As such, the Bush assertion that "you're either with us or against us," magnified by an evil Dick Cheney, and the CIA's complete break with past rules on interrogation, rendition, secret prisons, enhanced interrogation techniques and Machiavellian manuvers had put the hammer down, balls to the walls, whatever it takes to round these terrorists up. Hoffman's character is willing to lie and manipulate his own sources, but he is more focused on the "barracuda" who is in the film a Muslim cleric with a"moderate" veneer who others are willing to accept at face value. Issa, the hapless Chechen illegal immigrant, is seen, through the film, as just that ... hapless. Hoffman believes the cleric is a funnel for illegal funds that are laundered en route to al-Qaeda operatives. He seem intent on proving that point. However, the CIA, which is pulling even bigger strings, double crosses him in a deal against other German bureaucrats who want nothing to do with possibly allowing another operation against the U.S. to happen. They will cooperate with the CIA because the CiA has become ruthless & will punish anyone "against us." Hoffman's character is a hard drinker, hard smoker. If Hoffman was that aggressive an addict, as a recovering addict, I feel sorry for him. Prior to his death, I may have heard he was an addict in recovery. As with so many actors, they manage to not name the 12 step program they're successful with (which is an adherence to our traditions to not identify our affiliation with a specific 12th group at the level of press, radio, TV, film, internet). If he did that delicate dance, it may have been harder for him to walk in a room of AA or NA. As such, he may have simply begun a long, slow slide to overdose. Too busy with his career, he chose roles, I suspect, that fit the personna of the guy who uses drugs and gains power from that use. He forgot he was powerless. Perhaps, in the end, he represents powerlessness v. hopelessness, when all his efforts disintegrate. Wilhelm Dafoe is also an excellent surprise. Robin Wright plays a superbly amoral CIA agent ...one who will operate with very few rules, to ensure that the world is "a bit safer" under the new Bush-Cheney guidelines that THEY define the parameters for such safety ... i.e., the American definition is the one that counts. Anything less, will bring betrayal of even friends who believe they've made deals but want their own payoff ... the "baracouda" in this case wasn't enough of a catch. The CIA wanted who fed the baracouda. And even who fed the feeder of the baracouda. Down that road lies torture and Guantanamo. Even at this time, those men like Issa may still linger in Guantanamo. That net caught many who were minor players. But with someone like Dick Cheney still rolling around, pleased with the results of that era, the shadow of September 11, still looms large. Hoffman's character simply couldn't or wouldn't go that far. In the end, he lost. In the end, like Health Ledger, Hoffman may have given up his life for his desire to act so firmly. Personally, I'm always sad to see public figures die because they won't stay with "recovery" as their primary mission. Robin Willams and Health Ledger are just two more. All, great losses.

As someone who enjoyed TINKER, TAILOR, SOLDIER, SPY, I basically knew what to expect with this film. Instead of bombastic action, John Le Carre goes for a more subtle approach involving duplicity, backstabbing and double-crossing. Philip Seymour Hoffman leads the cast as Gunther Bachmann, a veteran German spy who runs a small outfit that uses informants as a way to catch bigger fish. And in a post-9/11 world, this represents a more scaled-back method than more controversial ones used by countries such as the US. The cast is rounded out by Willem Dafoe, Rachel McAdams and Robin Wright, who all give incredible performances alongside Hoffman, in one of his last film roles. In particular, Hoffman was excellent in portraying the world-weary spy. At times, it almost seemed like he wasn't even acting, with his heavy breathing and wheezing. The plot was rather straightforward, which was a nice change of pace from TINKER TAILOR. It tackled a timely subject with eloquence and simplicity, which I admired. The score was never intrusive, and came in at just the right moments. Overall, I quite liked it. I can understand if certain viewers might find it dry or boring, but for those who enjoy this type of spy movie that requires more of your attention, I can heartily recommend this.

If you're like me when you think of spy films the first thing that pops into your head is James Bond. You think of the gadgets, the girls and the suave, sophisticated agent doing his all to save the world. Rarely does someone think of characters like George Smiley, the docile looking bureaucrat from the John Le Carre novels that looked more like a banker than the spies we were used to. But chances are in the real world thats what spies really look like. And Le Carre has made a career of writing about spies like that.

A MOST WANTED MAN gives us another spy of sorts from the real world in the person of Gunther Bachmann (Philip Seymour Hoffman). Gunther is the head of an elite group in the German government in charge of seeking out possible terrorists and preventing them from attacks like those witnessed on 9/11. But the problems that occurred prior to that date continue in this country where various organizations fail to work together, each one wanting to take credit for the capture or killing of anyone deemed dangerous. Gunther is more in line to try and put the person hes after to use where as his counterpart sees termination as the best possible solution.

Most of the movie revolves around Gunthers team trying to find and handle a young man named Issa, an illegal immigrant who has come to Germany to collect an inheritance his father left him years ago. Where they first suspect him of being dangerous the more they find out about him the less they believe him to be a threat. Instead Gunther wants to use him to reach the people hes talking to, a banker and another man believed to be the main man in Germany funneling funds to terrorists. Gunther wants to use this man as a means to an end. His counterpart just wants to take him down immediately so he can take credit for one man eliminated from the list; he has no concept of the long term goals that can be achieved.

The story offers a back and forth on two levels. The first is the day to day handling of Issa and the people around him. How the team convinces others to work with them, making promises they might not be able to keep while influencing people with no known contacts with terrorists, make for an interesting topic in the film. The second level is between Gunther and the lead of his opposing team. Gunther wants to do the best work possible and prevent any attacks in the long run, his opponent just wants praise for taking someone out now.

While these stories are interesting in the long run they make for a very dry movie. There is almost no action involved in this film. There is plenty of discussion between characters and groups involved in the story as well as with participants dragged into the skullduggery involved in spying. Its more of a wordy film than one might expect when the word spies is used. If you know going in that the film moves at a slow pace then you will enjoy it. If Bond is what you're seeking then avoid it.

Many are flocking to this film and praising it solely because it is considered the last starring role for Hoffman who died of a drug overdose last year. Hoffman had a long career that had some great roles and others that in my observations didn't deserve the praise they received. Here he turns in an admirable performance as the chain smoking tired looking government bureaucrat trying to do his best and finding opponents on his side as well as those against his country.

In the end I cant recommend this movie for everyone but fans of Le Carre will want to check it out. Fans of Hoffman will want to see the movie as well. It isn't a bad movie but you have to know what to expect walking in. If you do youll find an entertaining evening here.

A Most Wanted Man," based on the 2008 John Le Carre bestseller, stars Philip Seymour Hoffman as German intelligence agent Gunther Bachmann, a heavy-drinking chain smoker whose attempts at exposing a Muslim terrorist ring are hindered by other agencies eager to root out the ring and score. Less about foiling terrorist plots than about differing approaches to dealing with the threat, the movie co-stars Robin Wright (House of Cards) as the face of the CIA, an ideologue eager to dictate how Bachmann should pursue a likely Al Qaeda middleman.

Director Anton Corbijn sustains suspense by focusing on how Bachmann and his team go about discovering the real identity of Issa Karpov (Grigoriy Dobrygin), a Chechen Russian from Turkey who turns up in Germany seeking political refuge. Karpov engages German human rights lawyer Annabel Richter (Rachel McAdams) to help him collect his deceased Russian fathers fortune from a German bank run by Thomas Brue (Willem Dafoe).

Inspired by true events, the film tracks the methodical, often tedious work of many individuals and organizations as they keep tabs on suspects and try to ferret out nefarious schemes, determining when to wait, when to follow leads, when to corroborate intelligence, and when to close in.

Hoffman looks very much the rumpled bureaucrat on top of his game. Hes no James Bond. In fact, hes exactly the opposite  sedentary, overweight, whose weapons are computers, intercepted communications, informants, and experience.

Bonus features on the Blu-ray edition include a digital copy, making-of featurette, and profile of John Le Carre in Hamburg.

It's a story with many subtle layers, and is definitely a film for the thinker. The movie is very well made, because it makes you think and leaves you no choice but to do so. However, it achieves this without being forceful about it. It's the kind of film where hours later you still pick up on nuanced exchanges between the characters. The acting was adequate all round, but Hoffman and his character stands out above the restwell acted. I would classify it as a drama/spy thriller.

****Semi-spoiler alert:*****
The story revolves around a German agent who collects information by making deep connections with people in the informant networks he builds up, caring about them, and tries to help them as human beings. He accepts that reality is complex and refrains from applying hyperbole and overreactions onto them, while keeping perspective of what the true, broad goals of intelligence collecting is. Ironically, he instills into his co-workers that there is no place for emotion and weakness in their jobs, and distances himself emotionally from them. Devastatingly to his emotional well-being, he gets betrayed by an American counterpart who he allowed himself to trust, despite initial reservations based on a previous incident. The end result is his guilt at having exposed his informants and players to harm after promising them a safe outcome. The film maintains a good pace and tensions throughout.

This is not Jason Bourne or Mission Impossible. If you're looking for that kind of fantasy-action thriller look elsewhere. However, this is an an excellent movie, grounded in the real world of post 9/11 intelligence. The acting is generally superb, especially from Hoffman and Robin Wright. Highly recommended for those who appreciate realism.

A MOST WANTED MAN is a 2014 British slow-burning spy thriller film based on the 2008 novel of the same name by John le Carr.  The novel is loosely based on the true War on Terror story of Murat Kurnaz, a Turkish citizen who was arrested in Pakistan in late 2001 and held by the United States at the Guantanamo Bay detention camp for five years. (Kurnaz was released and arrived in Germany on August 24, 2006.) The film premiered at the 2014 Sundance Film Festival.  Directed by Anton Cobijn, the Dutch photographer and film director of THE AMERICAN, the film is star-studded:  Philip Seymour Hoffman, Rachel McAdams, Willem Dafoe, and Robin Wright.  It is the last of Hoffman's films released in his lifetime.

The setting of both the film and the novel is in the post 9/11 city of Hamburg, the German port city where Mohammed Atta and his collaborators planned the 2001 American attacks. The plot is not complex. A half-Chechen, half-Russian, brutally tortured immigrant (Grigoriy Dobrygin) turns up in Hamburg's Islamic community, laying claim to his father's ill-gotten fortune. Both German and US security agencies take a close interest to determine this most wanted man's true identity.  Is he an oppressed victim or destruction-bent terrorist?

Gnther Bachmann (a grizzled and perpetually smoking Hoffman) leads a covert German intelligence organization that seeks to develop intelligence from the local Muslim community.  The identity of the immigrant is soon revealed: one Issa Karpov who is considered by many to be a potentially dangerous terrorist. Karpov contacts an immigration lawyer (Rachel McAdams) though a local Muslim family.  The lawyer visits a banker (Willem Dafoe), whose father laundered money for Karpov's father, and verifies the inheritance.

While director Cobijn captures the mood and atmosphere of post 9/11 Hamburg, A MOST WANTED MAN is not a nuanced character study like his 2010's THE AMERICAN with George Clooney. Once used to the German accent, you'll be impressed by Hoffman's rare leading man performance, which won raves at the premiere of the film weeks before his death.  He brings a world-weary quality coupled with a "deep understanding of human complexity and the reality that no one is either fully good or fully evil" to the role.

With the help of a young lawyer (whom he calls a social worker for terrorists), a cagey CIA agent (Robin Wright in a hideous black wig), and a shifty banker/money launderer, Bachmann conjures a convoluted and dangerous trap for a Muslim academic who's been backing terrorist activity via donations to a Cyprus-based shipping company.

A must-see...must-have DVD for fans of John le Carr and Philip Seymour Hoffman.

I saw this in theaters and I was ambivalent about seeing it at first. Reason being was that I saw Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy in theaters a while back hoping it was going to be good but was a disappointed. But because this was Hoffman's last leading performance, I figured I should try it. I was pleasantly surprised! The cast is solid inlcuding Ms. McAdams and Defoe! The story is relatively straight forward. It's at a slow pace but it picks up towards the end! It's definitely worth the wait! I was never a die hard Hoffman fan or a fan of John LeCarre and spy movies for that matter. But everything came in an awesome package! The film ends with an alternate version of one of my favorite Tom Waits songs "Hoist That Rag"! I loved that the director included this. The soundtrack itself is great with some regular songs and a full score with some accordion. Ultimately, I was left satisfied and sad that this was Hoffman's final performance. I really liked him in the recent "The Master". The film really adds an eerie undertone to the ending of Hoffman's life. He was a fine actor and will be missed. The general negative critiques of this film are that it's too slow and the performances aren't great, specifically Hoffman's German accent. Well, since movies are like eye candy nowadays for people who want something fast-paced and action packed, a slow thoughtful film like this will leave the average person "bored". With regards to the German accent, I thought it was well executed. I'm sure there's no ultimate German accent nor do I think American viewers are experts in this matter. But if you like Hoffman, John LeCarre novels, spy thrillers, good acting, politics, or maybe just good music, this film is for you! I'd highly recommend it as one of the best films of 2014!

John le Carré's brilliant novel A MOST WANTED MAN has been transformed into a screenplay by Andrew Bovell and Stephen Cornwell and as directed by Anton Corbijn the very complex story works well - primarily because of the performances of a near perfect cast. The theme is in keeping with John le Carré's loathing of the Cold War spying crimes and this particular story, though difficult to follow at times (a factor that helps the innate confusion of the spying and counterspying - a process examined by the film) it is a piercingly indictment of the machinations of the spying and terrorist techniques of all countries.

When Issa Karpov (Grigoriy Dobrygin), a half-Chechen, half-Russian, brutally tortured immigrant turns up in Hamburg's Islamic community, laying claim to his father's ill gotten fortune, both German - Günther Bachmann (Philip Seymour Hoffman), a worn-out, beat-up, used-up operative and his aides Irna Frey (Nina Hoss) and Maximillian (Daniel Brühl) - and US security agencies - Martha Sullivan (Robin Wright) take a close interest. One Human Rights Lawyer (Rachel McAdams) attempts to help Issa with the aid of Bachmann and Frey. As with almost all evil acts the villain is money - Issa has come to inform his father's best friend, banker Abdullah (Homayoun Ershadi) that the money he is to inherit must be given to charities (Issa vehemently disapproved of his father's ill-gotten gains). As the clock ticks down and the stakes rise, the race is on to establish this most wanted man's true identity - oppressed victim or destruction-bent extremist? A MOST WANTED MAN explores the dirty side of intelligence work complicated by counterspying and is a contemporary, cerebral tale of intrigue, love, rivalry, and politics that prickles with tension right through to its last desperately surprising scene.

Philip Seymour Hoffman is brilliant in this downbeat, distrusting, disheveled, difficult role and is well supported by a fine cast, including Willem Dafoe, the underused Mehdi Dehbi and Neil Malik Abdullah. The film is choppy, the accents and all spoken dialogue is rather difficult to follow, but the impact this anti-spying statement makes is well worth the time invested. Grady Harp, November 14

John LeCarre's books are always very subtle; written between-the-lines, so they don't always translate well to the screen because most people need to have everything spelled out. It's no surprise that many people just don't get them.

But this is one adaptation that works beautifully; very clear & easy to follow. Yet there are obviously a lot of people who still missed the point.

"A Most Wanted Man" is directed by Anton Corbijn from the screenplay (Andrew Bovell) which is based on the John le Carre' novel of the same name. An intriguing spy thriller that will seduce you slowly as this storyline is unafraid to take its time.  The suspense builds within the plot of cohesive storytelling. This film's direction is quite clever with its cast as they can leave you guessing from scene to scene. Philip Seymour Hoffman is Gunther Bachmann, who heads up a small "unknown" security division that carefully and methodically spies on new suspects coming into Hamburg, Germany.  Entering in under the cover of the nighttime is a half-Chechen and half-Russian man, Issa Karpov (Grigoriy Dobrygin).  He has been horribly tortured and has come to claim his late father's money from the banker, Tommy Brue (Willem Dafoe) while slipping into the Islamic community.  Gunther is on the case.  Hoffman is once again able to completely chameleon himself into another character and champions each and every nuance of his role.  His performance rivals anything he has done previously as Hoffman is a master of his craft and here he is again.

I was interested from the very start as the story added a new character and then another into its plot.  As on top of this as Gunther is American security agent, Martha Sullivan (Robin Wright).  They must know the true identity of Issa, who is he? Why is he here? What does he want?  Who is he really?  To help get some of these questions answered is Annabel Richter (Rachel McAdams), a "pacifist" lawyer, human rights activist hired to aid him by people in the community.  Gunther works tirelessly with Irna Frey (Nina Hoss) to stay one step ahead at all times and this is certainly not their first waltz together.  The film is generously cast and beautifully scored (Herbert Gronemeyer) with a soundtrack that ticks with its own tension adding to a potboiler at times.  This is a careful spin on a chessboard, a thoughtfully crafted piece in comparison.  It twists and turns right up to the ending, the ending that I will not even flirt with except to say, it cannot be missed.

I usually don't care a whole lot for spy thrillers as I get lost trying to follow difficult plotlines, twists that take me way off base or just plain confusing situations.  I did not find that here.  This is easy to follow, although it is still quite intricate, once you start becoming vested in the characters in the storyline. It almost transcends what you might expect from this type of film as there are no huge explosions or overblown anything. This is a mind craft.  One of this year's best in suspenseful views, "A Most Wanted Man" plays fair, not predictable but surely does not spin you away from the action and this is mainly all in the acting.  I was completely hooked from the point of pushing play ...

I saw this twice in the theater and thought it one of the best movies of the year, so far. Hoffman's performance is subtle and finely honed, a touch dark and melancholy. His German accent is perfectnever over-stated nor is his character's approach to the slow-moving detective work of solving a terrorist riddle along with  an over-bearing and clunky American effort to insinuate itself in the outcome. The plot moves along deliberately, no "Hollywood flourishes," which may be why some people find it "slow." If you like cerebral spy movies with great performances, I highly recommend this. If you are looking for hokey gimmicks and shoot em up action, you won't find them here. An excellent, although melancholy (obviously influenced by Hoffman's too early demise), espionage movie that harkens back to the Bush era.

Bore-fest.  Didn't care for any of the characters, the movie was boring, actionless and slow.  If you think bickering between which bureaucracy and morbidly obese man chain-smoking is "exciting" then this is your movie.

A half-Russian, half-Chechen immigrant named Issa (played by Grigori Dobrygin) shows up in the Islamic community in Hamburg to claim his inheritance left by his hated Russian father.  Germany has been a snakes' nest for terrorists and the German and American espionage communities are on edge.

Is this new arrival to their shores an Islamic extremist who is going to use his inheritance to perhaps blow something or someone up or fund attacks on the West?  That's what Gunther Bachmann (Philip Seymour Hoffman) and his off-the-radar small intelligence unit must find out.  They hope to enlist the aid of a banker (Willem Dafoe) and a young human rights lawyer (Rachel McAdams) as the clock is ticking before the big boys and girls step in.

Who are the good guys and who are the bad guys is a question you keep asking as is typical in a John LeCarre story.  If you like the slow, measured pace of a LeCarre plot, you may enjoy this more intellectual thriller.

I've read the other reviews here and I've got to agree with one thing that the "most critical reviewer" said. This was that although it is accurate and realistic to the bone, it drags in the middle because of its earnestness in covering such important material. He further contends it loses some of its entertainment value when it does this. I agree but I cannot grade it as low as 3 stars as he did. But that sagging in the middle should knock a star off.

I cannot fault any actor in the movie itself. They are all top notch. Hoffman has the lead and it is his final lead. He does a great job. As i understand it, he was already deeply in the throes of substance addiction but that sure didn't hinder his acting in top form, as per usual. Willem Defoe plays a German banker. I didn't believe he was German but otherwise he was fine. Actually, the only American I  came close to believing was German was Hoffman and even that was a stretch. But this could be from decades of watching foreign movies with subtitles so I know what a "real" German movie sounds like.

The plot is post 9-11. Germany is concentrating on Islamic terrorists just like everyone is. We are there, of course, in the form of Robin Wright and are ready to jump all over any government not "on" Islamic terrorists 24-7. The Germans have one lined up and they proceed to run him. They do all the things spies do minus any of the glamour. Hoffman looks like an unmade bed most of the time. He knows what he's doing but if you saw him on the street you would never think he was a spy. I am sure that is what real spies aim for as a goal. He is completely convincing.

Except for the dragging in the middle of the film, it is really quite good and I do intend to watch it again. It may even go up that final star on a second watching.

P.S.  I watched it again and it is still 4 stars.

"We both know he's innocent. I want to held." Gnther (Hoffman) is a German who works looking for terrorist threats and tries to stop them. When a Chechen Muslim is found living in the city German and US agents try to capture him. When Annabel Richter (McAdams) arrives she tries to convince anyone that will listen that the man is not a terrorist but a victim of Russian abuse and sending him back will endanger him. This is about the 1000th movie since 9/11 that focuses on hunting terrorists. For some reason they all seem to drag to me. I can't help but think of The Good Shepherd every time I see a movie like this. I think the problem with these are that they are very serious in tone to the point of almost being too serious. By that I mean that they try and show step by step what happens when the look for someone and that really tends to slow the movies way down. In terms of importance these movies are toward the top. In terms of entertainment they are near the bottom. This genre starts off strong and ends strong but the middle hour and a half really drags to the point of making it a struggle to get through. Overall, an important but not an entertaining movie. The best way to watch is see the first and last half hour, you will get the basis of what you need. I give this a C+.

This way, you can avoid telling the rest of us how boring it is. However, if you enjoy a dialogue driven story, as you go along on an investigative journey to trap a terrorist financier, then you'll like this one. The Hamburg backdrop is a nice addition, also.

Phillip Seymor-Hoffman , why does everyone think this drug addict is such a great actor drugs were a crutch for this guys supposed talent , anyone who needs drugs too enhance his performances is NO GREAT actor rather the opposite , this film would have been better without hiis being in it any number of actors could have played the part without the aid of drugs in his system. the film is excellent .

I found "A Most Wanted Man" to be a curiously flat film ; one that never quite came to life to enthrall and captivate the viewer. It is a slow moving spy drama (not a thriller) with few action scenes and not a lot of suspense. The film is set in Hamburg and follows the activities of Philip Seymour Hoffman's unhealthy,wheezy anti terrorist chief who sets up an elaborate sting operation to entrap a suspected Jihadist financier after a young Chechen illegal immigrant arrives in town. The rather plain looking Rachel McAdams plays the Chechen's lawyer , or terrorist social worker,as Hoffman labels her. The film plods along slowly as Hoffman sets up his sting which culminates in an unexpected dramatic ending. Hoffman doesn't look a well man in this film,chain smoking ,whiskey drinking and generally looking knackered throughout. I think this film is a reasonably intelligent,moderately interesting one, but one lacking in excitement and suspense. Not particularly memorable.

Lots to like, Hoffman is very good, I'm no gaga Seymour Hoffman fan -- I thought he was terrific as Art Howe in Moneyball -- but here is a sincere performance. Rachel McAdams's is at least as good, Nina Hoss's too (and both are very easy to look at), Robin Wright not so much, and it's hard looking at Willem Dafoe and seeing anything other than Willem Dafoe. (Too bad, because he's pretty good.)

A major flaw, though: Karpov. The lurking, menacing, sullen, silent, facing-the-wall refuge from Chechnya. It's a role we've seen so many times, in so many films, it's become really, really annoying and it's all the fault of director Corbijn.

"A Most Wanted Man" is one of those stories where even though this particular event did not occur you get the strong sense that it's filled with truths. Philip Seymour Hoffman plays Gunter Bachmann whose job is to run a small secret-from-the-public group in Hamburg, Germany to keep abreast of and address  potential terrorist threats. Much like the movie Captain Phillips, this film lets the viewer see all sides of the story. It breaks down the concept of "Good-guy" and "Bad-guy" into its more complex components. The movie starts with Issa a 1/2 Russian, 1/2 Chechen man sneaking into Hamburg; Issa has been imprisoned and tortured for the crimes of his Russian father, he's either been released or escaped and is a potential terrorist threat. Gunter and his female partner Irna, who he works with closely and loves deeply, immediately get Issa on their radar and start following his movements.

It becomes a game of "using the minnow to catch the barracuda to catch the shark." The film keeps the audience guessing as to which person is which fish. All the while the German and US officials are threatening on the side lines to jump in and knock down mid-step the intricate house of cards that Gunter and Irna are building. We find out mid-movie just why there is this bad blood between Gunter and the US through an official (played by Robin Wright of the show House of Cards) admitting to a past US mid-step that did much personal and career damage to Gunter. Now Gunter (as well as the audience) is all the more wary of who he can trust, with the government officials being arguably harder to decipher and read than the terrorists.

The film does a wonderful job of explaining new and complicated political concepts and spinning an intricate mystery in a palatable and understandable way. Highly recommend this topical film for both the entertainment, characters, fine-acting (with Hoffman at the top of his game), story and mystery side as well as to get a better grip on the world we live in today in terms of terrorist activity and untangling and combating it.

Whats it about?

A Chechen Muslim illegally immigrates to Hamburg seeking his fathers ill-gotten fortune, where he gets caught in the international war on terror. The story follows Günther Bachmann (Philip Seymour Hoffman) who heads up an anti-terrorism unit working in Hamburg to stop acts of terror before they happen.

What did I think?

Anton Corbijns background in still photography for lots of famous bands has clearly influenced the visual aspect of this film. Coupled with the mastery of Andrew Bovell (make no mistake, its nothing like his earlier effort Strictly Ballroom), John le Carres story and characters suck you in. The tension in this film is delivered subtly, before you know it you are on the edge of your seat. Anton, John, Andrew and Philip all in one place made this reviewer a very happy camper. A Most Wanted Man is PSHs last completed film and truly cements why Hollywood will feel his loss for generations to come.

Philip Seymour Hoffman (1967 -- 2014) portrays, Gunther Bachmann, the hear of a small German anti-terrorist investigation unit, in "A Most Wanted Man", completed just before Hoffman's death. Directed by Andrew Corbiin and based upon a John Le Carre novel, the film is set in Hamburg after the events of September 11. It portrays the conflicts between several anti-terrorist agencies, German and American, as they disagree about the means of uncovering a large terror-based organization with roots in Hamburg. The cast features a suspected terrorist who has been smuggled into Hamburg, a left-leading young attractive attorney who tries to help him, a Muslim leader in Hamburg who speaks of peace but who smuggles money to terrorists, and a woman operative from the U.S. State Department.  The movie develops slowly and carefully with a gradual increase of tension. The plot is easy to follow. The film offers as well excellent views of contemporary Hamburg. The movie has a highly topical interest with the continued threat of terrorist groups around the world. But the central attraction of the movie is Hoffman.  He portrays the chain-smoking, methodical, and disheveled Gunther Bachmann in a way which slowly develops his character and his experience together with his quiet strength in fighting terrorism. Bachmann is a figure with both substantial depths and substantial wiles in this, Hoffman's last role. "A Most Wanted Man" is well-worth seeing.

Robin Friedman

Anton Corbijn's "A Most Wanted Man" is a well-made, suitably depressing adaptation of a John Le Carre novel. Set in modern-day Hamburg, it stars Philip Seymour Hoffman as Gunter Bachmann, a cynical, hard-drinking intelligence officer heading a special anti-terrorism unit. His latest assignment is to track the movements of Issa Karpov (Grigoriy Dobrygin), a suspected Chechen terrorist who has literally washed up in Hamburg for reasons unknown. Others involved in the story include Annabel Richter (Rachel McAdams), an idealistic civil rights lawyer who tries to help Issa; Tommy Brue (Willem Dafoe), a shady banker who holds the secret of Issa's presence in Hamburg; Martha Sullivan (Robin Wright), a CIA operative with her own agenda; and Dr. Abdullah (Homayoun Ershadi), a Muslim philanthropist who may be funding more sinister projects than hospitals and orphanages.

Corbijn and screenwriter Andrew Bovell tip us off early, via the film's palpable sense of impending doom, that nothing good will emanate from the collision of these people. Nevertheless, the film is compelling, particularly as a showcase for excellent actors playing fascinating characters. As sad as "A Most Wanted Man" is, the saddest thing about it is that Hoffman, who so masterfully inhabits the skin of Gunter Bachmann, is no more. This is one of Hoffman's finest performances, and it is unbearable to think that, except for a handful of movies still awaiting release, we will not see him again.

There's not very many movies I've seen in the past year that measure up as well as "A Most Wanted Man". Granted, I've seen a lot of fun or interesting films that I definitely enjoyed, but this one really hits the mark in a way that others didn't. It transcends being entertaining and becomes its own sort of enigma. But I don't want to give the impression that it's hard to understand, because it certainly isn't. The plot is easy to follow (once you get used to the German accents) and each character has their own tendencies that you pick up on quickly, but I never quite knew what was about to happen. I was kept on my toes, or on the edge of my seat rather, and I appreciated how unpredictable it was.

Set in Hamburg, Germany, it centers around a secret group of anti-terrorism operatives lead by Günther Bachmann (Philip Seymour Hoffman). After coming across a brutally tortured Chechen immigrant who turns up in the local Islamic community, and is laying claim to his father's corrupt fortune, they attempt to establish his true identity and motives. And without spoiling some of its major plot points, I can say that it unfolds with a huge amount of style and elegance, while not being afraid to take its time.

It's the kind-of movie you'd want to curl up by the fireplace and watch on a cold winter night. Hoffman (who is never not smoking a cigarette in this) delivers one of the best performances of his career, rivaling his role in "Capote". And the direction by Anton Corbijn is outstanding, giving it a sharp and neat feel that carries throughout. The more I think about it, the more I like it. It's a definite must-see.

A Most Wanted Man - Phillip Seymore Hoffman's last movie before he OD'ed on heroin. John LeCarre has been writing spy books and movies since the fifties. He was an ex-MI6 agent, England's CIA. didn't care for Ian Flemings "silly" James Bond and his description of the activity of spies so he wrote books about real spycraft and spies, the arguably most accurate ever written. His first book made into a movie was, "The Spy who came in from the Cold" which came out about the same time as "Dr No".  He wrote "Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy" (the First six part Alec Guinness series is perhaps the best spy series ever done) and "Smiley's People". He wrote "Russia House", etc. Le Carre still keep writing them, fifty plus years late. He also directs this one, set in Germany.

Hoffman plays Gnter Bachmann. The German gov't can't spy on it's own people, by law. So they fund secretly Hoffman's group to spy on suspected  Taliban agents and Taliban supporters in Germany. The CIA and MI6 are also interested. Hoffman and his group carefully go after "minnows to catch sharks and sharks to catch whales". Consistently suspenseful like a pot of water brought to a slow boil. Le Carre himself says Hoffman's portrayal of the German spymaster is as good as Alec Guinness's wonderful portrayal of George Smiley, or better, and that is saying something. The first movie I've seen this year with an acting job worthy or a "best actor" award.

It is often hard to tell if Hoffman's character Bachman is old, tired, fat, overweight and smoking because of really superb acting or if the soon to be dead Hoffman was in that bad a shape.

Don't go expecting a lot of car chases and shootouts. LeCarre and Hoffman build tension gradually like in "Argo".

One of the first really quality movies this year

This is a slow moving spy drama. The film tries to create interest by explaining that the 9-11 bombings were planned in Hamburg. Recently a Russian-Chechen Muslim (Grigoriy Dobrygin) illegally immigrates to Hamburg. His father was a bad guy and his motives are suspect. He is represented by a lawyer (Rachel McAdams). Günther Bachmann (Philip Seymour Hoffman) heads up a local agency that is in charge of anti-terrorism. He has ties to the CIA and has bigger fish to fry.

This is not an action spy film. They don't shoot guns. The first 50 minutes or so build up the story and characters before it gets into gear and once in gear, it moved slowly along. I love Hoffman, but he sounded like he was attempting to do Churchill. The film has some good drama scenes, a few good lines, and a WTF ending I didn't see coming.

For those who loved the novel, or "Tinker, Tailor..." this should be perfect for you. Lovers of action spy films will find themselves dozing off as we see a more realistic story.

Parental guide: F-bomb. No sex or nudity. 3 1/2 stars

Theatrical review.  There may be spoilers.

In one of his last performances, Philip Seymour Hoffman, shows off his mastery of the acting craft as Gunther Bachmann, the leader of a small spy unit of the German government.  Assigned to Hamburg where the 9/11 terrorists hatched their plot against the United States, Bachman and his small squad are charged specifically with watching for evil doers within the Muslim community.

We see Issa Karpov (Grigoriy Dobrygin) slip into the country but he is soon identified as a possible Islamic extremist coming from Chechenia by way of Turkey.  Rather than pick him up, Bachmann allows him to "walk" as he puts it.  Followed all the time, Issa finds refuge with a Turkish family, then obtains legal help from a human rights lawyer (Rachel McAdams).  Is he a terrorist or not?  He is found to be the son of a deceased Russian general.  The general, it seems left a large fortune for the son with a bank now run by Tommy Brue (Willem Dafoe), himself the son the original banker and a friend of the general's.  But what is the money to be used for?  We find out as soon and Bachmann and his crew do at the same time.

Tightly directed, with the use of many hand held cameras, by Anton Corbijn ("The American"), the film bogs down slightly during scenes where Bachmann has to refocus his plan.  But make no mistake, each scene moves the story along, pretty rare these days.  If you are looking for a shoot-`em-up action film, this isn't it.  In fact the only violence has Bachman throwing a punch in a bar.  This is a scene-by-scene procedural that raises the tension level with each event.  Hoffman is brilliant as the slovenly Bachman.  He chain smokes, drinks whiskey in his morning coffee and has a hard time keeping his shirt tucked in.  He doesn't look well but plays the role to the hilt.  This is a very good, intelligent spy thriller.
As you watch, you despair the loss of PSH. A talented superb actor. The story, a political minefield for those, who try to do an honorable job in a nasty field. Smart.

This man has only written one book which I didn't think was first class.  Like myself, I hate the fact that he is aging and may not have too many stories yet to tell.  If you like Le Carre this is a must read.
good plot , good actors and a good girector

My Lord, this is some really good writing. Classic Le Carr'e, about very human emotions of people living life on the edge in a serious intelligence community. Amazing depth in storytelling, not for the faint hearted, when considering how serious the depth of emotion is here.
Terribly boring, slow movie.

An engaging and suspenseful plot which occurs in Germany during the cold war...Hoffman is terrific. Rachel Adams plays the activist lawyer committed to assisting those who enter Germany in unconventional ways. Interesting appearance by Robin Wright who has done better.
